entries: I can tell from experience how great of a campaign {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden} is. My favorite one so far, to be honest. Chapter 1 needs to cover a lot of ground. The designers focused more on creating entertaining quests than fleshing out descriptive elements of the towns; a good approach when you have a limited number of pages available. To bring the town descriptions up to the same level and lighten the burden on DMs preparing for their games, I felt the need to create this supplement.

At first, this project started humbly with only a few pages of notes. But the longer I worked on creating interesting and interconnected locations; the more pages I filled. In the end the page count was much higher than I had anticipated, so I put even more effort into the production to make it a comprehensive supplement DMs would consider using while preparing for their campaign.
I hope you find as much joy in this supplement as I had in creating the locations. Cheers.

data.name: Introduction
entries: The main goal of this supplement is to give Ten-Towns, as described in {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}, more variety. We've added plot hooks, encounters, connections between the towns, and some foreshadowing for events that will occur later in the adventure. This book describes new locations and builds on previously published lore from other works, including the {@i Legacy of the Crystal Shard} adventure and the {@i Icewind Dale - Setting Guidebook}.
This product contains:

items: {@b Interesting Locations}. 76 engaging locations in and around the towns, ranging from completely new places to expanded descriptions of existing locations found in the campaign book or known lore.

{@b Quests and Connections}. 13 mini quests and countless connections between Ten-Towns and the plots of the second chapter. Give your player more reason to travel around or get hooked to the various plots of the campaign.
{@b Town Events}. 37 random town events to set the mood of the harsh reality the folk of the dale currently live in and to keep investigating the towns interesting.
{@b Road Encounters}. 20 diverse road encounters to spice up travel between towns and to let characters have a taste of the dale's dangers.
{@b Expanded Sections}. Additional options for traveling, trading, sacrifices to Auril on new moon, and many more.
{@b Tables and Sidebars}. Numerous tables and sidebars offering overviews and additional information to enhance your campaign.
{@b Cross-References}. Dozens of cross-references to the Rime of the Frostmaiden campaign on DnDBeyond and to other helpful resources.

entries.name: Gambling Folk
entries: When characters enter a tavern, patrons may already be drinking and gambling. Most gamblers are willing to let newcomers join their game. A character wishing to join a game must bet at least 5 gp every hour they gamble and make three ability checks: Wisdom (Insight), Charisma (Deception), and Intelligence (Investigation). If the character has proficiency with an appropriate gaming set, they can use that proficiency in place of one skill in any of these checks. The DC for each ability check is {@dice 5 + 2d10}, with separate DC's generated for each skill check. Consult the Gambling Results table to see how the character did (see {@variantrule Downtime Revisited|XGE} in chapter 2 of {@i Xanathar's Guide to Everything}).

Gain the amount you bet plus half again more.

entries.name: Dire Times
entries: The locations described in this supplement don't always mention they were impacted by the endless winter. Many people have died or left Icewind Dale, and trade from outside the region is at a standstill. Most shops, inns, temples, and other establishments seem empty or depressed, lacking in goods, employees, and customers. Everybody is doing their best to persevere.

entries.name: Low Supply
entries: When characters try to buy something, roll a d100. On a 20 or lower, the requested items are not in stock or unavailable in the desired quantity. The merchant will then inform the character their order needs at least {@dice 1d6} days to be filled. The merchant's stock will not be replenished until this time has passed.

entries.name: Different Prices
entries: If you wish you can offer items at different prices in each town emphasizing supply and demand. {@link Here|https://www.dmsguild.com/product/329148} you can find a good reference to do so.

entries.name: A Merchant's Escort
entries: Merchants from smaller towns visit Bryn Shander, Termalaine, or Easthaven to restock on goods. When characters visit a tavern, inn, shop, or marketplace and present themselves in a friendly manner, they might be approached by a traveling merchant. The trader asks them if they would be willing to escort them and their wares back home for a reward of 10 gp.

Merchant escorts are a great device to encourage characters to travel to new towns. Most merchants travel by foot with a sled full of wares they pull behind them. Consider using the Encounters on the Road table in appendix A or create your own encounters to make the journey challenging.
You can find more options to generate random NPCs in greater detail or use pre-generated NPCs {@link here|https://www.dmsguild.com/product/359013}.

entries.name: Getting around Ten-Towns
entries: Most folks prefer dogs over axe beaks because they are generally easier to breed, train, and require less food. Thus, dogs are more often offered for rent or sale in stables. Axe beaks have some advantages over dogs, as only four are needed to pull a sled as compared to six dogs, plus they are 25 percent faster, each pulling up to 420 pounds. However, dogs require only half a ration per day, while axe beaks require two. A character without proficiency in Animal Handling has disadvantage on Wisdom (Animal Handling) checks to steer, calm or otherwise interact with axe beaks compared to dogs. Characters can be taught to handle axe beaks by the stable masters in Bryn Shander and Easthaven.

entries.name: Renting a Sled
entries: Characters can rent a sled with six dogs or four axe beaks for 5 gp per day.

entries.name: Travel Times
entries: If you wish to adjust the travel times, you can find a good cheat sheet for it {@link here|https://www.dmsguild.com/product/328657}.

entries.name: Spellcasting Services
entries: Characters can receive spellcasting services from an NPC at temples in Ten-Towns. Consult the following table for price suggestions.

These are the spells that are generally available. To receive more powerful spells, characters must find the aid of powerful allies. Additionally, a {@spell remove curse} spell might require the characters to find additional components, making it harder to break the curse.

entries.name: Preparing Locations
entries: This supplement contains combat encounters and provides suggestions on adjusting them for smaller or larger groups, characters of higher or lower levels, and characters that are otherwise a bit more powerful than the supplement is optimized for. Don't feel bound by these suggestions; they're here for your convenience.

To determine if you should adjust the encounter, add up the total levels of all the characters and divide the total by the number of characters (rounding .5 or greater up; .4 or less down). This number is the group's Average Party Level (APL). To approximate the party strength for the supplement, consult the following table.

entries.name: Sacrifices to Auril
entries: Bryn Shander, Easthaven, and Targos sacrifice people on the nights of the new moon to appease Auril the Frostmaiden. Roll on the Sacrifices to Auril tables in the appendix A to determine the ill-fated person.

Each town has their own ways of handling the unamiable act. Bryn Shander closes its gates and holds a census, allowing volunteers to represent a household, and where Inns and Taverns such as The Northlook are considered a household. Easthaven gives everyone a number for anonymity, but a description for each person is noted in case they don't come forward. If you don't accept a number, you'll be banned from town. Targos takes the names and description of everyone who enters or leaves town through their only gate, and then publicly declares the sacrifice at high noon. If the victim doesn't turn themselves in immediately, a manhunt begins within minutes. The guards and officials loyal to Zhentarim aren't in the lottery as well as anyone who offered a considerable bribe to the speaker Naerth.

Most will not leave town before the lottery because they would need to survive alone in the tundra or spend the time in another town with its own problems. Those who sacrifice food are usually dangerously low on supplies and don't welcome unexpected guests. Towns sacrificing warmth are only slightly safer than staying on the tundra itself during the new moon, since all light is extinguished for almost 20 hours and no guards will patrol the town.

entries.name: A Home in Icewind Dale
entries: Auril's winter made the harsh life of the north even more dire, forcing some people to move or starve. In every town, characters can find closed businesses and abandoned buildings. Most city speakers are happy to offer an abandoned building to individuals willing to create something out of them.

In addition, some named locations in the adventure may be claimed by characters. Some of these locations might need serious repairs, while others must be cleared of their residents or come to an agreement with them to receive shelter.

entries.name: Bremen
entries: Founded by dwarven prospectors, this town was ruled by barbarians for a time. Bremen has a higher number of small folk than other towns, in stark contrast to the tall humans living here. Almost half the buildings are designed for dwarvish height. Many structures were built to last, sacrificing beauty and elegance for robust and sturdy layouts. Over the years, several halflings settled here as well, hoping to put their natural luck to good use. The town is in decline. Almost half of its houses are abandoned, clearly demonstrating the severity of current times.

entries.name: Friendliness: 3/3
entries: The town is accustomed to a periodic flow of fortune hunters seeking the treasures that wash up on their shores. The townsfolk have learned that much can be gained from a little openness to strangers.

entries.name: Services: 1/3
entries: Apart from a single shop selling trinkets of questionable usefulness, there are no other stores in town. People have little to offer and can share none of it with strangers.

entries.name: Comfort: 2/3
entries: The town has only one inn, but the proprietor does everything to ensure customers have a good stay, sacrificing her comfort to do so.

entries.name: Buried Treasures
entries: {@i Inn}

Dozens of objects dug up from the river decorate the common room. Lighter spots on the wood are signs of where things of value once hung for years. Now only items of symbolic or decorative value like driftwood and broken weapons remain, except for a single gold nugget in a glass case, which in truth is a painted rock. Cora, the proprietor, used the painted rock for years to inspire visitors to treasure hunt themselves.
The inn is usually cold, but if guests arrive, Cora greets them and immediately starts a fire to warm the room. She then reheats fish soup, enough for everyone.

Guests staying overnight are brought to the last two furnished bedrooms in the inn. Four other rooms exist, but they lack furniture as Cora sold them out of necessity. Cora normally keeps the last remaining brazier in her room, but she gives this to any guests staying overnight, along with additional blankets. The following morning, Cora is visibly exhausted, having slept little through the freezing night. She forces a smile and waves off any concern, offering her guests another free bowl of fish soup or a heartfelt goodbye.

entries.name: Ewin's Trinkets
entries: {@i Curio Shop}

This small store specializes in buying and selling trinkets found on Bremen's shores. Ewin (lawful good lightfoot halfling {@creature commoner}) purchased the store after a lucky find of some gold nuggets. Business has been poor since the start of Auril's winter, but the shop remains cluttered with innumerous trinkets and baubles. Some look as if they might have value to the right person, while others look like the kind of trash a child would stuff in their pockets to keep it from being thrown away.
Ewin sells his trinkets with a warning he is not responsible for any undiscovered or undesirable magical effects. He also buys small gems.

entries.name: Magical Trinkets
entries: Some of this collection dates to the wizard who ran this store before Ewin. Characters can buy various strange things here (see {@item trinket|PHB|trinkets} in chapter 5 of the {@i Player's Handbook} or {@item icewind dale trinket|IDRoTF|trinkets} from the appendix A of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden} for more inspiration). A trinket has a 10 percent chance of having a minor property or quirk (see {@book "Special features"|DMG|7|special features|0} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: Magical Waterski
entries: A character spending at least 10 minutes searching through the giant collection can make a DC 20 Intelligence (Investigation) check or cast the detect magic spell and make a DC 13 Intelligence (Investigation) check. On a success, the character discovers a waterskin made from Otyugh hide, which functions as a {@item tankard of sobriety|XGE} ({@i Xanathar's Guide to Everything}). All liquor drunk from the waterskin has a lingering rancid taste for 10 minutes.

entries.name: Five-Tavern Center
entries: {@i Five unaffiliated taverns}

entries.name: Tavern Fights
entries: Fights occur almost every night in or a round these taverns. See the {@adventure "Five-Tavern Fist Fights"|IDRoTF-TTE|2|five-tavern fist fights|0} sidebar for more information.

entries.name: Stones
entries: The tavern is furnished in the simplest manner possible. Cracked mugs cover broken and hastily repaired tables. The owner gave up replacing damaged furniture because of the never-ending barfights. Whatever decorations the common room once held are long destroyed and thrown out. The tavern gets its name from the polished river rocks the barkeep Duff Kilm (chaotic neutral Turami human {@creature bandit}) puts at the bottom of every tankard of ale. If a drinker drains the cup at a single go, the stone rolls gently down to the lip of the tankard, but patrons who delicately sip at their beer will get a crack in the teeth when they throw back the last of their drink.

entries.name: The Grumpy Moose & The Bearded Brother
entries: Two different-looking adjacent houses with separate tavern signs and entrances lead into a joint common room. The connecting wall collapsed during a violent bar fight, which only escalated the brawl further. After calming down, the arguing brothers who owned the houses saw the merit of two doors leading into a single tavern. One sells ale, while the other tries to win over guests with strong liquor. The original brothers are long gone (or perhaps never existed), but the tradition is kept alive by the current owners Jalurn Bhiln (neutral shield dwarf {@creature commoner}) and Vormul Marftid (lawful neutral gold dwarf {@creature commoner}). They often argue and shout profanities at one another to the amusement of the patrons, but they always put the interest of the combined tavern over their frequent quarrels.

entries.name: Even Keel
entries: Proprietor Kalxom Pack Twistnipper (chaotic good rock gnome {@creature commoner}) has a sour demeanor and frequently tells cynical jokes likely a result of being exiled from his original home. His attitude has made it difficult to win over customers. He tries to combat this by creating a pleasant atmosphere, using small clockwork constructs to play soothing music, and adding herbs to give his ale a unique spicy flavor. Hard-pressed by nearby competition, Kalxom tried to copy the combined tavern idea by buying the abandoned tavern next to his.

entries.name: The River's Mouth
entries: The tavern's windows are tinted, making it impossible to see inside, but a welcoming, warm light and soft music emanate from within. In truth, the tavern is empty, having recently been purchased by Kalxom from the Even Keel next door. Behind every window sits an oil lamp while a small clockwork construct plays the same tune all night, though the rest of the building is empty and neglected. Customers entering the tavern are directed through a narrow hallway of makeshift walls. This passage turns sharply right, ending at a door opening into the Even Keel tavern.

entries.name: Five-Tavern Fist Fights
entries: Roll a d1oo. On an 80 or lower, there will be a bar fight between {@dice 3d4} {@creature commoner|MM|commoners}. They all fight each other; but no weapons or lethal blows are allowed. On 40 or lower, characters inside or directly in front of a tavern can't avoid being pulled into the fight. On a 20 or lower, the brawl escalates; use the lair actions listed below. The fight ends when no more than a quarter of the original combatants stand.

items: {@dice 1d4} additional {@creature commoner|MM|commoners} are pulled into the fist fight.
A chair or similar item gets thrown. A random character must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or take ld4 bludgeoning damage.
Someone swings with a full mug of ale. A random character must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or become blinded until the end of their next turn.
The fight becomes chaotic. Every creature with at least two other creatures within 5 feet must succeed on a DC 10 Strength saving throw or fall prone.

entries.name: Fishing Contest
entries: Characters who visit the central area between these taverns for the first time are met with a raucous atmosphere; as the tavern owners are hosting their quarterly fishing contest. The goal of the contest is to motivate people to replenish their supply of trout and simultaneously attract customers. The rules are simple. Everyone interested should form crews of up to four, with each crew equipped with a rowboat and fishing tackle. Whoever catches the most trout before dusk; wins bottles of fine liquor (worth 10 gp per bottle) and free ale for the next three months in one tavern of their choice (see {@adventure "Fishing for Knucklehead Trout"|IDRotF|0|fishing for knucklehead trout|0} in {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).

If characters decide to join before completing the "Lake Monster" quest; run it during the fishing tournament (see {@adventure "Lake Monster"|IDRotF|2|lake monster|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}). The characters will compete three other groups, consisting mostly of people from out of town and either oblivious of the lake monster threat or daring enough to ignore it.

After the first hour, a man gets pulled into the water by an incredibly strong trout; but his group manages to retrieve him from the lake. They immediately set course for shore hoping to save him from a cold death. When the second hour passes, the characters can see one of the remaining boats get jostled. Its passengers start to frantically bail water and head for dry land. After the third hour, the last competitors catch their fourth trout. Seemingly assured of victory; they return to shore not willing to risk themselves further.

entries.name: Riverbanks of Shaengarne River
entries: {@i Frozen Treasures}

Bremen is known for the treasures and trinkets which get washed upon its riverbanks after the early summer's seasonal floods. Auril's winter froze the water and brought an abrupt halt to this, depriving Bremen of its touristic treasure hunters. But there are still valuables to be found beneath the ice. A character who prospects on the beach for at least 1 hour has a 50 percent chance of finding something. Roll a d6 and consult the Treasures Beneath the Ice table to see what the character finds.
It takes 1 hour to break the item out of the ice using a tool like a pickaxe. Every item can only be found once. Rolling the same result on the table again means the character finds nothing.

rows: A frost giant's ring (worth 2 gp, or  worth 20 gp to researcher or  antique collector)
A part of a stone tablet covered in runes

The left-half of a stone tablet. Runes in Giant read: "...and prove yourself at Jarlmoot". The backside shows a rough map of Icewind Dale, indicated by the forms of the lakes, showing no exact destination, probably broken away on the right part of the tablet (see {@adventure "Jarlmoot"|IDRoTF|12|jarlmoot|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).
A 1-foot-long key made of rusty  iron. Who knows what it is for?
A withered piece of expertly crafted scrimshaw (worth 5 gp, or worth 30  gp if restored)
A piece of wreckage from a fishing boat
entries.name: Treasures Beneath the Ice
entries.caption: Treasures Beneath the Ice

entries.name: Town Hall
entries: {@i Town hall (and speaker's residence)}

This small building was used for town planning, particularly the annual floods that plagued the town. Nowadays, sporadic emergencies shifted to ever lingering burdens, leaving the town hall largely unused. Unreadable stone tablets, ruined paintings in moldy frames, broken parts of a giant's massive weapon, and other peculiar finds from the shores sit on shelves as a reminder of a more prosperous past.

entries.name: Speaker's Chambers
entries: The upper floor's height was built to accommodate dwarves. There is a 50 percent chance that the speaker's rooms are abandoned, with speaker Dorbulgruf wandering confused along a shore or riverbank. The rooms' tidiness contrasts with the abundance of strangely misplaced objects: paintings have been taken from the walls and placed on chairs, dishes stacked on the floor, flowers lie neatly sorted next to their vases, important documents rolled up and stored in winter clothing, and so on.

entries.name: Bryn Shander
entries: Bryn Shander is the newest and probably busiest of TenTowns. Its buildings show less signs of age, and most have a second story. Auril's winter left many houses abandoned in other towns, but this is not the case in Bryn Shander. Many fled to this town, believing it the best place to survive the cruel cold. It is not unusual to see houses occupied by several families at once. While not a city like Waterdeep, the town is still filled with all sorts of people and races.
Consult the {@adventure Town Encounter|IDROTF-TTE|-4|town encounters|0} table in appendix B to see what events can occur in this city.

entries.name: Friendliness: 3/3
entries: As the first town most travelers reach when coming to Icewind Dale, its inhabitants are accustomed to strangers and happy to get new customers. Residents know they are better off than most other towns and therefore willing to offer a helping hand.

entries.name: Services: 3/3
entries: As the trade hub of Icewind Dale, people can find most goods and services in or near Bryn Shander's marketplace.

entries.name: Comfort: 3/3
entries: Bryn Shander is the largest of the ten towns, offering a wide variety of taverns and inns in nearly every price category.

entries.name: Abel's Arcana
entries: {@i Magic Shoppe}

This rusty old house is home to the overweight Abelerion 'Abel' Heavywood (chaotic good sun elf {@creature commoner}). The bronze-skinned, blonde elf has four open locks on the front door leading customers directly into his living room. Since his life was saved by the healing hands of a cleric of Ilmater, the old elf decided to live every moment to its fullest, primarily by feasting like there is no tomorrow. Visitors to his 'shop' have a 75 percent chance of finding him dining at his table. Anyone watching him devour food might believe that Icewind Dale is a land of plenty where food is abundant. He won't let patrons interrupt his meal, pointing customers to a single cabinet filled with a seemingly random assortment of magic items. Abel will answer questions with his mouth stuffed with food. He offers a 10 percent discount to any cleric or paladin on their first purchase.

Abel is well off even in these dire days. He sells magic items to fortune-seekers and other rich folks. His assortment is nothing to brag about, but it is one of the few locations in the whole dale where magic items are sold. To determine his inventory of magic items, roll or choose up to three items from table F and one item from table G from the ' Magic Items ' in Chapter 7 of the Dungeon Masters Guide. In addition, roll or select up to three common magic items from ' Common Magic Items ' in chapter 2 of Xanathar's Guide to Everything.
Once Abel sells his last magic item, he will close his shop and travel to Waterdeep to buy new inventory. He returns to Bryn Shander after two tendays.

entries.name: Quirky Items
entries: Abel has a strange sense of what he considers 'good.' The items in his store have a 50 percent chance of having a minor property or quirk (see {@book "Special features"|DMG,7,special features,0} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

entries.name: Armory
entries: {@i Armory and Guard Post}

As the name indicates, the armory stores the town's weapons and armor, but this building also serves as the nearest guard post to the market square and has a ballista mounted on its roof. Two {@creature guard|MM|guards} are always stationed in the small guard room. They have the key to the steel door, which separates the guard room from the storage.

When characters first arrive near the armory, they see Sheriff Markham talking in a suppressed angered voice to the two guards about the recent disappearance of weapons. If a character asks what happened, the sheriff is startled because his frustration with the guards distracted him. He gives a glance to see who else might be listening and then quickly changes the topic with a fake smile, hoping to avoid starting rumors about how incompetent his militia is.

entries.name: 'Official' City Request
entries: If Markham hasn't met the characters, he asks if they are sellswords and offers them the job to hunt down the {@creature snowy owlbear|IDRoTF} terrorizing the caravans near the Eastway. He will pay up to 150 gp for an owlbear's complete and undamaged remains but will pay only a fraction of this amount if the beast's form is damaged in any way. He offers no further explanation. This is not an official city request but a private one from a conniving merchant. The merchant has already paid the sheriff for any owlbear's intact remains as he is planning to discreetly sell it as a stuffed trophy to a wealthy customer in Waterdeep.

entries.name: Stolen Weapons
entries: If characters continue to ask why the sheriff was angrily talking with the guards, he pulls them closer and tells them in a low voice of the armory's missing weapons. He insists they keep quiet about this and will pay 50 gp if they arrest the thieves and bring back the weapons. Local thugs bribed the guards of the armory, but the guards deny knowing anything. A character succeeding on a DC 12 Wisdom (Insight) check sees through their faÃ§ade. A successful DC 13 Charisma (Persuasion or Intimidation) check causes the guards to reveal the truth as long as they are not in a public space. The guards feel guilty but were desperate for coin because of these dire times. The guards will share they opened the armory to a half-orc named Zarruk. They don't know where sh e is but can give a decent description of her appearance and suggest asking around in lowerend taverns or inns (see {@adventure "The Hooked Knucklehead"|IDRoTF-TTE|2|the hooked knucklehead|0} in Bryn Shander). Markham will regretfully accept this news as he assumed something like this would be the case. He will only lightly punish the guards by assigning them another duty.

entries.name: Blackiron Blades
entries: {@i Smithy and Outfitter}

The main room is filled with cabinets neatly organizing every piece of equipment an adventurer could need, including weapons but no armor. Each cabinet is low enough to allow a dwarf easy access to the upper shelf. Behind a dwarven-sized reception desk stands Elza (neutral good shield dwarf {@creature commoner}), a 4-foot-tall dwarf with short curly copper-colored hair and a muscular build.
She sells all weapons at 75 percent of the price listed in the Player's Handbook because of their lower quality. The weapons are plain, without any decorations, and have the following trait:

entries.name: Low Quality
entries: When you roll a 1 on your attack roll with this weapon, the weapon takes a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to damage rolls. If its penalty drops to -5, the weapon is destroyed.

entries.name: Council Hall
entries: {@i Meeting place for city speakers}

This building is large enough to accommodate all the council for the towns' irregular meetings. The large central chamber contains a spherical table with ten armchairs surrounding it. Adjacent rooms include items servants use to support speakers, including food and drink, maps of Icewind Dale, Bryn Shander, and nearby regions, as well as a lavatory. The upper floors are luxuriously furnished guest rooms for the speakers.

entries.name: Debate
entries: There is a 20 percent chance to meet Duvessa here, meeting with the city speaker from Easthaven, Lonelywood, or Termalaine.

entries.name: Geldenstag's Rest
entries: {@i Lackluster Inn}

This drafty inn is located near the east gate and run by the old widow Myrtle (lawful good Illuskan human {@creature commoner}). Her husband died in a dispute with mercenaries. Myrtle is a nosey woman who asks many questions, refusing rooms to anyone who keeps secrets. Her quirk attracts honest folk who prefer a quieter stay in Bryn Shander.

Characters who are friendly and talk with Myrtle or one of her customers for 5 minutes or more can make a DC 10 Charisma (Persuasion) check. On a success, they are pointed to an acquaintance in the market square where they can buy tools or adventuring gear at a 10 percent discount.

entries.name: Thieves' Cant
entries: Thieves cant is a secret mix of dialect; jargon; and code allowing people to hide messages in seemingly normal conversation (see Rogue" in chapter 3 of the Player's Handbook). Here  is an example conversation Zarruk might have with her companions:
{@b {@i Zarruk:}} "Haven't seen you two in a while." {@i [we need to lay low]}
{@b {@i Companion:}} "Ha, you're right; friend. How long has it been?"
{@b {@i Zarruk:}} "Dunno, man. Feels like forever to me. How's your family?" {@i [we need to act now]}
{@b {@i Companion:}} "Don'task that; you know, its only nagging and shouting: rather go to a tavern and share a drink with just Irlon here. You?" {@i [we work alone; no others involved]}
{@b {@i Zarruk:}} "Same, same." {@i [I also work alone]}
{@b {@i Companion:}} "We were just talking about Hallan. Have you heard about his health?"
{@b {@i Zarruk:}} "Ahh, you know him. He will be back to good health even when the rest of us is already frozen stiff!" {@i [it will be an easy job]}
{@b {@i Companion:}} "Strange fellow. He definitely hasn't inherited this from his old man. He's been dead for almost thirty years." {@i [payment 30 sp?]}

{@b {@i Zarruk:}} "Your memory must be pretty bad. He is dead for just twenty years. I am sure of it. You know what. I have some fish soup on my old brick stove home. Its awful, I already fed some to the pigs. I need to grab some new on my way back." {@i [payment 20 sp; warehouse of Brickbrow, guards were bribed, where do we stow the goods now?]}
{@b {@i Companion:}} "Doesn't surprise me with your lousy cooking skills. My wife can do some good. Wanna bite?" {@i [I know a good place]}
{@b {@i Zarruk:}} "Haha, sure. Let's go."

The original reference can be found {@link here|https://www.dmsguild.com/product/245143}, as well as some further {@link inspiration|https://old.reddit.com/r/DnDBehindTheScreen/comments/8k8g8k/oh_yes_thieves_can_cant/}.

entries.name: The Hooked Knucklehead
entries: {@i Trader inn}

This long-standing inn caters to traders and scrimshanders. The proprietor Barton (neutral Tethyrian human commoner) was a trader himself and a regular guest until he bought the inn. He prefers to stay out of other peo ple's business.

The common room is spacious, with tables spaced far enough apart that the sound of wind whistling through cracks in the walls makes it difficult to overhear quiet conversations. Nosy characters must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check to overhear other's conversations. The few private rooms on the second floor contain no hearths and are primarily used as trader's meeting rooms, with guests preferring to sleep in the common room close to the large marble fireplace.

entries.name: Stolen Weapons
entries: The half-orc Zarruk Tuskripper (chaotic evil half-orc {@creature thug}) and her two cloaked companions ({@creature thug|MM|thugs}) are here discussing the best way to sell the weapons acquired from the armory. They speak normally but use thieves' cant confident few will understand their conversation. No Wisdom (Perception) check is required to eavesdrop on the discussions inconspicuously. They agree to move the stolen weapons to a safer location and wait a few days, hoping for the Sheriff to calm down. The 'Thieves' Cant' sidebar offers an example discussion characters may hear. After some time, the thieves leave and walk to Tharrom's Warehouse, a small building a few blocks from the armory. One of the thieves uses a key secretly copied from the warehouse's owner. The stolen weap ons are hidden within boxes of other stored items. The thieves then move the stolen goods to an abandoned building beside the city's north wall.

items: Very weak: replace Zarruk's companions with {@creature bandit|MM|bandits}
Weak: replace one of Zarruk's companions with a {@creature bandit}
Strong: use the {@creature bandit captain} statistics for Zarruk

entries.name: House of The Morninglord
entries: {@i Shrine of Amaunator (god of the sun)}

Mishann removed several walls from the main building to expand its foyer into a larger worshipping area. Two wooden pews stand in front of a small dais holding a fist-sized sun forged from polished copper and enchanted with a continual flame spell.

The rest of the building contains rooms any typical house would have, including several unused guest rooms. A stair leads to the attic where the gnome Copper Knobberknocker has a private room and modest workshop.

entries.name: Healing
entries: Characters can buy healing services from the clergy here.

entries.name: House of the Triad
entries: {@i Temple of Ilmater, Torm and Tyr}
This impressive temple is made of smooth marble covered by a steep slate roof. Three corner towers rise 80 feet high, each emblazoned by a single large holy symbol representing Ilmater, Torm, or Tyr.

The 15-foot-tall double doors open into a large prayer room, with murals decorating the pillars and walls. Three simple but beautifully made statues depicting the gods of the temple stand in the back. Three entrances lead to annexes, over which rise t he temple's towers. The high priest of each god has a room atop one of the towers.

Ilmater's annex stores medical supplies to treat the wounded and a door leading to the small outside garden. Torm's annex contains barrack -like rooms, an armory, and a direc t connection to the stable. Tyr's annex offers an elaborate library used by the monks and priests of the temple.

entries.name: Healing
entries: Characters can buy healing services from the clergy here.

entries.name: Foaming Mugs
entries: Characters might also encounter the dwarves Hruna, Korux, and Storn getting their frostbitten limbs treated at the temple (see {@adventure "Foaming Mugs"|IDRotF|3|foaming mugs|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).

entries.name: A Plea for Help
entries: When characters visit the temple for the first time, they are approached by pastor Borren Farwick (lawful good Damaran human {@creature priest}). He asks them if they need anything. After some conversation, he tells them about one or more towns in need of sellswords. He can share rumors from Bremen, Caer-Konig, Dougan's Hole, Lonelywood, or Termalaine.

entries.name: Kadu's Wondrous Scrolls
entries: {@i Scrolls and inks}

The shop's entrance is adorned with a curled sheet of copper engraved with arcane runes symbolizing a spell scroll. The interior walls are made from duskwood, helping to keep the weather and especially the humidity outside. The orderly interior includes a counter lined with decorated ink vials and pens fashioned from feathers of different birds.

Kadu 'Owl' Banfyx (neutral good for est gnome {@creature illusionist wizard|mpmm|illusionist}) prefers to spend her days inside her shop, having as little contact with others as possible. The golden-eyed gnome wears thick spectacles. She lets customers browse her wares openly displayed in glass cases while she sits quietly behind the counter on a pile of cushions, thinking about her poems or novels. In an attempt to be polite, she created an illusion of herself which smiles and makes inviting gestures to customers.

Kadu sells spell components, inks, and a small collection of spellbooks and scrolls. She keeps exactly one copy of each scroll, quickly replenishing sold ones. Her spellbooks contain {@dice 3d6} spells, with 50 percent being 1st level spells, 30 percent being 2nd level, and 20 percent being 3rd level. Spellbooks costs are calculated from the sum of spells they contain: 25 gp for each 1st level spell, 75 gp for each 2nd level spell, and 150 gp for each 3rd level spell. She will buy spellbooks at half the price using this same formula. She can procure other spell scrolls through her contacts in Waterdeep.
If not already seen, Kadu reveals herself when a customer decides to buy or sell something. She always presents a patient and helpful personality. Consult the following table for prices.

entries.name: Kelvin's Comfort
entries: {@i Popular tavern}

Kelvin's Comfort is one of the most popular taverns thanks to its wide variety of dwarven ales and brandies. Rich caravanners with coin to spare frequent this establishment. The common room is decorated in dwarven fashion, and its grey painted walls give it a stone-like appearance. Axes and hammers line the walls between the paintings of mighty dwarven battles and even mightier dwarven drinking bouts. Most of the brandies are imported from Mirabar, where Ogden Flamebeard (neutral good shield dwarf commoner) still has many contacts. Ogden's signature drink is a Mirabarian rotgut he rebottles as Flamebeard's Firebrandy.

entries.name: Missing Mead
entries: One exception to his many imports from south of the Spine of World is an ale from Good Mead which remains a customer favorite. If Ogden recognizes the characters as adventurers, he tries to get on their good side by offering them a free drink before casually chatting with them. If Ogden feels the characters are trustworthy, he offers to hire them to deliver two barrels of ale to Good Mead as trade for a box of bottled mead. Ogden will pay 20 gp for the service. If the characters decline, he shows his fiery temper, immediately asking them to pay up for the free drinks he provided.

entries.name: Foaming Mugs
entries: Characters might also encounter the dwarves Hruna, Korux, and Storn here drowning the pain of their frostbitten limbs with liquor. (see {@adventure "Foaming Mugs"|IDRotF|3|foaming mugs|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).

entries.name: The Northlook
entries: {@i Inn and tavern}

Mounted above the hearth in the common room of the Northlook tavern is the giant knucklehead trout named Ol'Bitey. A wizard cast a spell on it so that it occasionally sings the verse: 'There's a place I like to go. Farther up the river's flow. Where it is, I do not know. Must be under all that snow.' The 'Ol'Bitey's Longing' sidebar explains this in detail.

entries.name: Ol'Bitey's Longing
entries: The place described in Ol'Bitey's song actually exists. To find it, characters need to travel north of Lonelywood to where the river flows into Maer Dualdon and then follow it north about ten miles. A character who walks along the river can make a DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) or Wisdom (Survival) check. On a success, the character discovers a 4-foot-diameter opening into the riverbank hidden beneath fog. The bottom half of the tunnel is filled with a small stream that empties into the river. A character who dives into the river finds the opening automatically.

Anybody touching the water feels that it is warm: If characters follow the narrow tunnel, they will reach a small cavern after a few hundred feet. A hot spring fills the grotto, making the air comfortably warm. Lichen covers the walls.

entries.name: Hot Spring
entries: Once per day, characters who spend a short rest inside the spring can reduce their level of exhaustion by 1.

entries.name: Kaant
entries: There are 30 doses of {@item Kaant|KaOSCaTGtID} that can be harvested from inside the grotto. The chamber regrows 3 doses per tenday. If the number of doses is reduced below 15, it stops regrowing for {@dice 1d4} months.

entries.name: Market Square
entries: {@i Market}

The thriving market of Bryn Shander is the focal point of trade in Icewind Dale. Fishers, crafters, and merchants from the other towns all converge here. Caravans from the Sword Coast, dwarves from Ironmaster and Kelvin's Cairn, and rarely, hunters from goliath tribes of the tundra all meet here as well. Pelts and expertly crafted scrimshaw are bartered for lumber, dyes, wine, textiles, and other wares imported from the south.

Covered in heavy winter clothes and standing next to their fiery braziers, merchants call out to customers to view their goods. Many old stalls made from weathered wood and covered with thick tarpaulin are packed close to each other to protect against the howling wind. In the center of the market stands a 9-foot-tall pole inlaid with gold and silver, engraved with holy symbols of Waukeen, goddess of trade. Around the pole lie countless copper and silver coins offered in the hope of good trade. Taking any of these coins is a sign of disrespect and shunned by the locals. Merchants will refuse to trade with anyone they see stealing these coins.
One can find nearly everything in the market square, ranging from fruits and spices to second-hand armor and weapons, though no magic items are openly traded here.

entries.name: Bad Weather
entries: The open market offers little protection against the weather. When it becomes unbearably cold, merchants will close their stalls for the day.

entries.name: Memorial
entries: {@i Statue of Tiago Baenre}

Just outside the south gate of Bryn Shander along the Ten-Trail stands a memorial visible from the city's wall. In the center of a 30-foot-circle of scorched earth atop a 2-foot-high dais stands the life-sized statue of the drow Tiago Baenre who triumphed over the balor Errtu and saved the city of Bryn Shander. The statue stands heroically, his shield resting relaxed in his left hand and his sword proudly raised to the sky. A plaque on the dais reads: 'On this spot did Master Tiago slay the demon. And the snows will cover it nevermore.'

entries.name: Worshipper of the Frostmaiden
entries: Nymetra (see {@adventure "The Wet Trout"|IDRoTF-TTE|2|the wet trout|0} in Easthaven), or another worshipper of Auril, may reward 50 gp for the destruction of the memorial. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of abjuration magic emanating from the statue. A {@spell detect evil and good} spell or similar magic reveals a demonic aura from the blackened earth. Anyone entering the area feels a sharp updraft of air from the warm temperatures inside the circle. Ranged attacks from outside the area have disadvantage against creatures inside of it. An attack against the statue transforms it into an {@creature animated armor}, its sword into a {@creature flying sword} and its shield into a {@creature flying shield|IDRoTF-TTE}. All three have immunity against fire damage and are not able to leave the area.

During the day, combat has a 50 percent chance each round to alert {@dice 1d6} {@creature guard|MM|guards} on the wall, who rush to defend the statue. The guards need two rounds to arrive at the site. During the night, the chance to alert the guards drops to 25 percent, and they need an additional round to open the gates before reaching the area. Characters captured by the guard are put on trial. If found guilty, they must pay a fine of 100 gp each for fighting the statue or 1000 gp if they destroyed the statue and are no longer welcome in Bryn Shander.

items: Very weak: remove the {@creature flying sword} and {@creature flying shield|IDRoTF-TTE}
Weak: remove the {@creature flying shield|IDRoTF-TTE}
Strong: add two {@creature smoke mephit|MM|smoke mephits}
Very Strong: add four {@creature smoke mephit|MM|smoke mephits}

entries.name: Peaona's Oils and Elixirs
entries: {@i Potions & herbs}

Peona (lawful good strongheart halfling {@creature druid}) runs this small establishment bordering the market square. Peona has shoulder-length black hair braided in six tails smelling faintly of roses. In front of the store sits an old copper bathtub on clawed feet. It is filled with glowing swirling liquids, which mix and separate erratically. The liquid is an accumulation of her failed creations. Characters are free to take from the tub, but she advises against drinking it as she doesn't know what effect it will produce. Anyone who drinks or applies the liquid onto themselves is immediately affected by a {@table Wild Magic Surge|PHB}.

The shop's interior is oppressively narrow, with only enough space for three Medium or Small sized creatures (including Peona). Potions, oils, lotions, ointments, and dried herbs are stacked high on shelves and reachable with attached ladders. The door behind the counter leads to her magically lit and heated greenhouse. There Peona grows all the plants necessary to produce her wares.
Peona keeps {@dice 1d4} of each of the following potions and 1 jar of {@item keoghtom's ointment} in the locked cabinets of the shelves. Consult the following table for prices.

entries.name: Rendaril's Emporium
entries: {@i Trade house}

Rendaril (lawful good half-elf {@creature commoner}) refurbished the old cabin that predated Bryn Shander to create his emporium. The front of the building faces the marketplace and is always kept clean, while a large entrance in the back allows traders to offload their wares.

The interior of the store resembles an upper-class jewelry shop in Waterdeep. Everything is meticulously organized and polished, displayed in masterly crafted oak cabinets and shelves. The store encompasses two floors. Rendaril and his two employees offer everything one might find in the market and more, including adventuring gear, weapons made in the Dwarven Valley, fishing rods with elven yew, yeti-skin coats with scrimshaw buttons, mithral fishhooks, and more. Rendaril knows that customers might find some things cheaper in the market, but he is more than willing to elaborate why the quality of his wares compensates for the higher price.

His centerpiece items are a {@item mithral half plate armor} for 1,500 gp and an {@item elven chain} for 5,000 gp presented on mannequins made from weirwood and enchanted with anti-theft wards. These armors are displayed so they are the first things seen on entry. If someone tries to move the armor while Rendaril is not within 30 feet, all doors and windows of the first-floor lock with an arcane lock spell. Additionally, weapons, shields, and armor fly from nearby shelves animating both centerpiece items into {@creature helmed horror|MM|helmed horrors} that attack thieves. These helmed horrors are immune to the {@spell heat metal}, {@spell shatter}, and {@spell shocking grasp} spells.

entries.name: Other Equipment
entries: Rendaril is willing to order other dwarven or elven crafted masterpieces for customers willing to pay up front and wait for their fabrication.

entries.name: Speaker's Palace
entries: {@i Speaker's residence}

Among the town's many wooden houses, this walled two-story stone building with its slate roof feels out of place and seems as if it were magically transported here. It is the residence of Bryn Shander's city speaker Duvessa Shane (lawful good Illuskan human {@creature noble}). Duvessa is rarely found at her luxurious home, spending most of her time at the council hall or the town hall debating and negotiating.

entries.name: Stables
entries: {@i Stables}

This is one of the largest buildings in town. Its entrance opens onto a stair leading up to a second floor, which is the private living space of Shratha Wolfherder (lawful good half-orc {@creature commoner}) and her wife Fhai Kua (lawful neutral Sho human {@creature veteran}). The second floor is centered around a common area, from which three small passages extend, each with a pair of doors opening off of them. One of these passages includes a spiral staircase returning to the ground floor, from which lively barking is heard. The ground floor consists of a huge barn divided into smaller animal kennels and a storage room for sleds. A large double door opens to the back of the building.

The two women buy, sell, and rent sleds, dogs, and axe beaks. At the moment, they have {@dice 6d10} trained dogs, {@dice 3d8} axe beaks, and {@dice 4d4} sleds to offer (see {@adventure "Getting Around Ten-Towns"|IDRotF|1|getting around ten-town|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).

Shratha is a soft-hearted person presenting herself as a quiet and unapproachable orc. She whispers in Fhai's ear when she wants her to relay a message because she is embarrassed by the discrepancy between her muscular build and her heavy lisp. Fhai fell in love with her precisely because of this awkwardness. Fhai is rough around the edges but tries to be a welcoming person to support Shratha. If someone makes fun of her beloved, she gets enraged and shows people that she hasn't forgotten her old days as an adventurer.

entries.name: Axe Beak Course
entries: Shratha can teach characters how to handle axe beaks. Training takes three hours and costs 10 gp per person. To successfully learn these skills, a character must roll three DC 10 Wisdom (Animal Handling) checks and succeed on at least two of them. A character who passed the training no longer has disadvantage when handling axe beaks (see {@adventure "Getting Around Ten-Towns"|IDRoTF-TTE|1|getting around ten-towns|0} in the introduction).

entries.name: Vellynne
entries: Fhai is working on a custom-made sled for Vellynne Harpell in the barn. It will be slightly bigger, offering enough room for her four kobolds, and will allow it to be pulled by eight instead of six dogs. There is a 25 percent chance that Vellynne is there as well, watching the progress.

entries.name: The Subtle Solution
entries: {@i Esoterics and poisons}

Unlike most businesses in Bryn Shander, this store is located at the edge of the town, hidden in a little-used alleyway. One of the first things visitors notice is the strong scent of cinnamon when they enter. The pale violet tiefling Nowhere (lawful evil tiefling assassin) runs this store. She wears a ring of mind shielding containing the soul of Heask Brighttong, an infamous con-artist from Waterdeep and the last person the tiefling assassinated. Nowhere often seems absentminded during conversations as she gets easily distracted by the never-ending stream of words from Heask. She telepathically complains to Heask about this, but she hasn't yet sold the ring, implying she is secretly grateful for the possessed spirit. Heask was the reason she quit her old job and fled to Icewind Dale.

Nowhere sells esoteric oils, incense, powders, candles, amulets, and homeopathic medicine. She describes all the wondrous effects and the correct way to use her wares to customers through a fake smile, suggesting they end neck pain, keep one warm during the coldest of nights, ward off evil, act as lucky charms, and so on. In truth, she doesn't believe one bit in them and only repeats what Heask tells her. Each item can only be used once, and they cost between 1 and 20 gp each. Once per day, as an action, a character can use one of these items for a chance to gain inspiration for the next 24 hours. A given item has a percentage change of providing inspiration equal to its gp cost. For example, a character performing the correct rite with their 10 gp lucky charm has a 10 percent chance of gaining inspiration due to their belief in the item.

entries.name: Master Poisoner
entries: In addition to her esoteric store, she sells {@table poisons|DMG}, a fact known only to people in shady circles. She still keeps her shortsword poisoned and always within reach beneath the counter.

entries.name: Tharrom's Warehouse
entries: {@i Warehouse}

This building is a warehouse in central Bryn Shander where traders can temporarily rent space to store their wares. Tharrom Brickbrow (lawful good gold dwarf {@creature commoner}) is the owner, and he keeps a detailed list of every customer and their wares. The structure consists of one large room (20 feet x 40 feet) with boxes, lumber, and other trade wares neatly stacked on top of each other.

entries.name: Stolen Weapons
entries: Zarruk Tuskripper has stored stolen weapons from the armory here (see {@adventure "Armory"|IDRoTF-TTE|2|armory|0}' and {@adventure "The Hooked Knuckleheads"|IDRoTF-TTE|2|the hooked knuckleheads|0} in Bryn Shander). The weapons are hidden in four wooden boxes beneath a canvascovered shipment of lumber. The first two boxes contain ten short swords each, the third box twenty daggers, and the last box six light crossbows. The boxes are 3 feet long, 2 feet wide, and 1 foot high, weighing 40 pounds each.
A successful DC 13 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals a small symbol on the handle of each weapon, identifying them as city property.

If the characters don't intervene, Zarruk and her companions move the wares to a decrepit, abandonedlooking house near the northern wall of Bryn Shander. This is actually a Zhentarim safehouse with a fortified cellar where they sell weapons to the Zhentarim who work for Targos' city speaker Naerth Maxildanarr.

entries.name: Town Hall
entries: {@i Town hall}

Bryn Shander's town hall is the largest building that borders the central square. It is reserved for community events on various holy days and celebrations. The hall was also built to house refugees from other towns in case of an emergency. Its ground floor consists of an assortment of smaller meeting rooms surrounding a large hall. They are plainly furnished allowing them to quickly turn into shelters. Several nearby storage rooms contain countless bedrolls, blankets, and stockpiles of dried food and medical supplies.

In the back of the hall, a short flight of stone steps leads to the basement. Timber beams reinforce frozen, hard-packed earth walls, while the floor is laid with smooth stone slabs. Sheriff Markham has set up his office close to the guardroom. Two dozen holding cells with steel doors are also nearby. One of his two deputies can be always found in the office willing to relay messages.

A stair in the entrance hall leads to the upper floor where the speaker's and the clerk's offices are located. Duvessa spends most of her time here, working on legislation and handling the town's current social and logistical problems. Duvessa's goal is to advocate for unity and to mend Ten-Towns' broken relations.

A ladder at the end of the hallway leads to a narrow attic holding the town's chronicles. Dusty cabinets are filled with ancient scrolls and contracts. Diaries of former speakers sit in these shelves speaking of old times. With a successful DC 10 Intelligence (Investigation) check, characters reading through the chronicles can find the lore of Akar Kessell's war against Ten-Towns. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, they can also find lore on Jarlmoot (see {@adventure "Jarlmoot"|IDRoTF|12|jarlmoot|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}) and Revel's End (see {@adventure "Revel's End"|IDRotF|12|revels'end|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).

entries.name: Vellynne
entries: There is a 25 percent chance to encounter Vellynne Harpell in a discussion with speaker Duvessa. Vellynne tries to gather information about Revel's End and the Arcane Brotherhood mage Vallish Gant (see {@adventure "Revel's End"|IDRotF|12|revels'end|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}). She also hopes to test Duvessa's willingness to cooperate or cut a deal.

entries.name: Cear-Dineval
entries: Caer-Dineval is a hamlet of weathered and hardened dalefolk. Where other folk fled to the safety of Bryn Shander, here the villagers have remained with their caer. Buildings show the signs of numerous attacks left by orcs and barbarian tribes. Every inhabitant has at least one simple weapon in their home. The only thing surviving from the villagers' old Cormyrian days is their respect for people wielding magic. Magecraft is seen as ever helpful in daily life and the direst situations.

entries.name: Friendliness: 2/3
entries: Caer-Dineval is far from a lively place. Its people are troubled by the endless winter, and they keep mostly to themselves, but they are still willing to talk to strangers.

entries.name: Services: 1/3
entries: In these dire times the villagers are hard-pressed to keep themselves alive and sustained. There are no shops in town. People have little to offer and can share none of it with strangers.

entries.name: Comfort: 1/3
entries: The only inn is closed and abandoned. The tavern is out of ale and refuses to give strangers a place to stay for the night. Characters looking for a place to rest must rest in an abandoned building or find some other solution.

entries.name: Culver's
entries: {@i Collector of curiosities}

Culver's home is one of the larger houses in Caer -Dineval. The resident, Culver Ailsen (lawful good Chondathan human {@creature commoner}), is an old widower and the first to speak to traveling merchants, share stories, and buy all kinds of oddities with a tie to Icewind Dale's history.

His home is filled with books, strange trinkets, countless forms and styles of scrimshaw, tools, old weaponry, animal trophies, plants, and other odd items. He has so many things that he is forced to use his table and stools as shelves, leaving him with only a single usable armchair. His most prized possessions are relics acquired from the Battle of Icewind Dale, Akar Kessel l's war against Ten-Towns. With a successful DC 16 Intelligence (Arcana) check, characters can spot a vase and a dagger blade made from pure chardalyn. Culver knows these are made of chardalyn but will under no circumstance ever sell them. He can share the story behind chardalyn (see "The Crystal Shard" in the introduction of the {@i Legacy of the Crystal Shard}).

Culver is interested in anything related to Ten-Towns and Icewind Dale history and is willing to share what he knows. Choose or roll up to three tales from the Tall Tales table (see {@adventure "Tall Tales"|IDRotF|12|tall tales in ten-towns|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}) to determine what Culver knows.

Speaking the name of his late wife Susanna backward animates a {@creature rug of smothering|MM} found in his living room. The animated rug will move to defend Culver. The rug needs 1 round to free itself from the many items Culver has placed on it.

entries.name: Dinev's Rest
entries: {@i Closed inn}

The closed inn is a spacious building. The past owner was Kaldie, who was the daughter of the previous city speaker before Crannoc. A year ago, she sold all her belongings and left, though nobody knows why.

Behind the boarded windows on the first floor is a big common room and a kitchen, pantry, and a bedroom. The second floor of the building is divided into four small rooms and two larger ones. All rooms are completely emptied of furniture, and only torn banners adorned with Caer-Dineval's heraldry line the walls and floor of the common room. A successful DC 12 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals the central fire pit has slumped downwards from the persistent freezing conditions. Any fire lit within the firepit fills the common room with smoke in one hour.

Six {@creature duergar} hide inside this ramshackle inn and remain out of sight until Xardorok's chardalyn dragon attacks the town (see {@adventure "Dinev's Rest"|IDRotF|4|dinev's rest|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).

entries.name: Knucklehead Harbor Warehouses
entries: {@i Harbor warehouses}

When the characters arrive at these warehouses, they will witness a rowdy dispute between a young man from Caer-Konig named Kavod Arente (chaotic good Illuskan human {@creature commoner}) and a group of anglers from Caer-Dineval.

Kavod is a tall, slender man in his twenties. He is terribly naÃ¯ve and not the brightest candle in the shed, wholeheartedly believing that he is right. He loudly demands trout from one of the men, accusingCaer-Dinevaltruding into their fishing territory. Kavod inherited the fishing business from his father but was so bad at fishing that he has never caught a single fish himself.

The discussion is leading nowhere. Caer-Dineval's folk abrasively respond to every complaint by telling Kavod to talk to their city speaker, who they know is not available. The disagreement eventually erupts into a fight. If the characters don't intervene, the five fishermen (human {@creature commoner|MM|commoners}) will beat Kavod until he has 1 hit point left.

If the characters intervene, the fiCaer-Dinevalk off but are not willing to split their catch. They gloatingly offer to lend the characters fishing tackle and one of their boats if they are hell-bent on helping Kavod. Before the characters can ask Kavod further questions, he tells them a heart-touching story of his planned dowry that needs two knucklehead trout (see {@adventure "Fishing for Knucklehead Trout"|IDRotF|0|fishing for knucklehead trout|0} in {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}). He offers them a surprising reward for their help.

He never reveals the name of who he loves, only referring to them as his beloved 'northern flower,' owner of the Northern Light inn in Caer-Konig. He is not talking about the lithe and charming Allie but of her stout and scowling sister Cori.

If characters successfully help Kavod and escort him back to Caer-Konig, he rewards them with his fishing tackle and his old barely floating rowboat. He will be completely oblivious to any complaints and tell the characters his future as a great inn owner is now assured and how happy he is that his fishing days are at an end.

entries.name: Ruined Watchtower
entries: {@i Ruin}

Stacks of rocks form dozens of small towers within the ruined walls of this old watch tower. Its half-crumbled wall s provide some protection from the region's persistently cold winds. The walls are covered with numerous round snow markings.

The children of the town use this place as a playground. The kids regularly compete to see who can stack the highest rock pile. The snow markings are from repeated snowball fights. The children will rebuild any destroyed rock tower after a few days.

If characters start to build their own towers or try to increase the height of existing ones, a single chwinga emerges from the wall curiously watching them. If treated well, the chwinga will stack its own small rocks, encouraging competition with the characters. Competing characters must make a Dexterity (Sleight of Hands) check. The character with the highest roll builds succeeds in constructing the tallest tower and is bestowed with a Charm of Snowball Strike by the chwinga (see {@filter "New Chwinga Charms"|rewards|source=IDRotF} in appendix C of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).

entries.name: Run Away Dog
entries: The children who normally visit the tower are currently playing with a stray dog in the town. This dog belongs to Olamin (see {@adventure "Stables"|IDRoTF-TTE|2|stables|0} in Easthaven). The children don't want to part with their new friend but may be convinced with a successful DC 10 Charisma (Persuasion) check suggesting that its owner misses it dearly.

entries.name: Watch
entries: There is a 25 percent chance of finding Skelm, Avarice's raven familiar, sitting atop the tower, lazily watching the town. Skelm reports any unusual or armed newcomers to its master.

entries.name: Caer-Konig
entries: Having been under the rule of barbarians and being one of the most northern towns in the region, many of its residents are descendants of reghed tribes. Some townsfolk are even former reghed tribes folk who gave up on their nomadic lifestyle or were cast out. Most are tall women and men who pride themselves on their sturdy builds, their ability to hunt, fish, survive in the north, and their mental fortitude. Tokens and small shrines worshipping nature are common in most houses.

entries.name: Friendliness: 2/3
entries: The people of Caer-Konig are split evenly between folk who prefer their seclusion and business owners who accommodate adventurers traveling deep into the frozen wasteland. A small gesture of kindness or a few friendly words might be necessary for residents to warm up to strangers.

entries.name: Services: 2/3
entries: Locals only trade for their daily necessities at the market, but characters will find adventuring gear available scattered among several small establishments in town.

entries.name: Comfort: 3/3
entries: Caer-Konig offers only one inn and one tavern, but characters will always find a table with enough food or a well-furnished room and friendly face to serve them.

entries.name: Ruined Caer
entries: {@i Ruin}

The decrepit state of the caer consists of bent wooden palisades and the rubble of weathered stones. With a successful DC 12 Wisdom (Survival) check, characters find numerous axe beak tracks leading to a place sheltered from the wind and roughly cleared of rubble. During the day, there is a 75 percent chance of encountering a wild {@creature axe beak} which made its home in the ruins, while at night, this rises to 100 percent. The axe beak's torn harness indicates it once belonged to an expedition. In truth, the axe beak belonged to a group of adventurers killed by Dzaan who found the lost Netherese spire ({@adventure "Lost Spire of Netheril"|IDRotF|12|lost spire of netheril|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).

Characters who spend one hour may calm the agitated beast with a successful DC 12 Wisdom (Animal Handling) check. A failed check results in the axe beak stomping threateningly. If this check fails by 5 or more or someone approaches the axe beak before calming it, the creature attacks. If the axe beak has 10 hit points or less, it will try to flee. Repeating the Animal Handling check on a calmed axe beak tames it, but a failure results in the creature returning to its agitated state. All Wisdom (Animal Handling) checks are made with disadvantage if the axe beak is awoken from its slumber at night.
The inhabitants of Caer-Konig can tell characters that an axe beak has lived here for a few tendays. Residents know enough to keep their distance to avoid provoking it.

entries.name: Snow Fox' Hideout
entries: {@i Hide, herbs and potions store}

An old woman named Foxes in the Snow (neutral tabaxi druid) lives in this run-down store. She has white fur with dark brown stripes and is the only doctor in the town. Foxes prefers that people only come to her in emergencies. Despite her age, she hunts for herself and knows the lands within two-day walking distance very well.

entries.name: The Unseen
entries: The inside of her home looks nothing like a shop. The building has only one room with a bed and a small kitchen. Weathered shelves are filled with containers of dried herbs, bones, pelts, vials of common medicine, and healer's kits. Foxes had a friend enchant her two windows with glyphs of warding. If someone tries to open the windows from the outside, the glyph targets the intruder with the {@spell tasha's hideous laughter} spell. If someone asks her about the thefts, she tells of hearing a deep voice laughing a few nights ago when someone touched her window, but she didn't care enough to look who it was.

With a payment of a big fish or a successful DC13 Charisma (Persuasion) check, a character can convince her to help look for traces of the thieves. She will send out her two trusty snow owls to scout the area. After one day, the owls report back that several bipedal creatures with dark skin and white fur entered strange stone formations in the mountain to the north. The owls are referring to the duergar outpost in Kelvin's Cairn (see ({@adventure "The Unseen"|IDRotF|5|the unseen|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden})).

entries.name: Frost Druids
entries: Foxes knows of the frost druids living in Icewind Dale, but she prefers not to engage with them. She can tell characters the names and appearance of these druids and warn them of the druid's awakened beasts.

entries.name: Snowy Baubles
entries: {@i Smith and adventuring outfitter}
Visitors looking to buy something here will find themselves in front of locked doors. A passerby can tell them that they need to talk to Trovus about the store.

Evy and her husband, Bron Bearhammer, ran the shop. Bron worked as Caer-Konig's smith repairing damaged gear while Evy carved scrimshaw. They often ventured together with Jarthra from Frozenfar Expeditions into the Dwarven Valley, looking for precious stones which Bron would forge into trinkets and other baubles. The shop sold adventuring gear and jewelry. They were known for their specialty scrimshaw accessories inlaid with precious stones and shards.

entries.name: The Unseen
entries: The shop has stood empty for a few days. Evy and Bron simply vanished one evening, leaving behind all their belongings.

The two were murdered when duergar unintentionally woke the couple while breaking into the shop searching for chardalyn. In their struggle with Bron, he ripped out hairs from one of the intruder's beards (see {@adventure "The Unseen"|IDRotF|5|the unseen|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).
Trovus keeps the key to the building. If the characters offer their help to find Evy and Bron, Trovus will let them investigate the house and share the following information about the couple:

items: Bron was a descendant of the barbarian tribes who once lived in Caer-Konig. He stood 6 feet and 5 inches tall. He had a shorn bald head, was not very talkative, and was easy to anger, but generally very organized and tidy.

Evy was the complete opposite. She was a small, sturdy woman with silky blond hair. She never seemed to run out of things to say or do, always keeping a positive outlook. Evy also had a habit of teasing her husband.

entries: Characters who search the building find it clean and tidy. Nothing appears stolen or broken. The walls are adorned with wild animal pelts, and cabinets display small wooden statues and other carved pieces. A successful Intelligence (Religion) check identifies these as tokens of Uthgar, the patron deity of Uthgardt barbarian tribes. Trovus can tell the characters that Evy often gifted these items to her husband to calm his anger.

Only the sheets on the couple's bed are slightly messy, suggesting they were used a few days ago. With a successful DC 10 Wisdom (Perception) check, characters find a small clump of bristly white hair possibly ripped from its original owner and smudged sprinkles of dried blood on the door frame leading to the bedroom. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, characters discover a small iron box with a carefully broken lock. Inside the box are found several semi-precious stones worth 20 gp in total.

Characters looking for clues who succeed on a DC 12 Intelligence (Investigation) check recognize that a glass display case filled with meticulously organized amulets and scrimshaws appears to be missing a few pieces.

The duergar took trinkets resembling chardalyn. Bron and Evy are no longer alive and can be found as spore servants in room O7 at the duergar outpost. If the characters solve the duergar mystery, Trovus will reward them with a hunting trap and a lock from Bron's possessions.

entries.name: Speaker's House
entries: {@i Speaker's residence}

The town speaker of Caer-Konig lives in this one-story building. Currently, this is the dragonborn Trovus. The east side of the house consists of a meeting room furnished with a large wooden table and six chairs. A spiral staircase leads to a turreted peak where the city's chronicles are kept. The building's west side contains a mostly unused kitchen with enough tableware to entertain a large number of guests and a pantry filled with additional stools, food, and alcohol. The northern part of the building contains a bedroom with a large double bed and a cabinet filled with clothes as well as Trovus' armor and weapons. Scattered throughout the building are empty bottles of liquor.

entries.name: Dougan's Hole
entries: People of Dougan's Hole are closer to the gods of nature and their isolated lifestyle than they will ever be to a friendly face visiting the town. Luxury is seen as a sign of waste by most, with few exceptions. The townsfolk only build what is necessary and practical. The facades of the town's many old houses show countless signs of repair.

entries.name: Friendliness: 1/3
entries: The folk of Dougan's Hole are the most distant in all Ten-Towns, physically and emotionally. They let outsiders know that they would rather be left alone.

entries.name: Services: 1/3
entries: There are no shops in town. People have little to offer and will share none of it with strangers.

entries.name: Comfort: 1/3
entries: There are no inns or taverns in town. People, including the city speaker, don't let strangers into their homes.

entries.name: Fishhouse
entries: {@i Warehouse and town hall}

The Fishhouse is a one-story warehouse standing along the pier. The nauseating smell of fish mixed with mold fills the building, and the stench remains on everyone and everything for an hour or longer after leaving.

The warehouse's space is barely used. It contains two small boats in need of repair, an emergency stockpile of wood, a few small barrels of salt, and several lines of hanged fish. The open area is used as a gathering spot for town meetings.

entries.name: Speaker's House
entries: {@i Speaker's residence}

The largest and oldest house is the former residence of the town founder Dougan Dubrace. Heavy logs stacked atop each other give the building a solid appearance and one capable of weathering the strongest storms. Time has faded its once pristine form. The building leaks and is drafty but still gives an impressive aura compared to the shabby surrounding buildings.

The interior of the building consists of plainly furnished spacious rooms. The attic contains two guest rooms, but the current city speaker Edgra Durmoot will not rent these to strangers. Apart from Dougan's engraved ancient fishing pole, the only decorations found throughout the house are dozens and dozens of simple scrimshaw trinkets of various quality. Most were made by Dougan himself, but it has become a tradition for a city speaker to create a new piece each year in honor of their founder.

entries.name: Twenty Stones of Thruun
entries: {@i Triangle of megaliths}
The Rime of the Frostmaiden campaign leaves the origin of the stones a mystery. Here are some further suggestions:

items: The oneshot {@link "King of the Wolves"|https://www.drivethrurpg.com/en/product/168693/dungeon-220-4e} from Dungeon #220 (page 32 - 55) describes the origin behind the stones. If you want to preserve Isarr Kronenstrom, king of the wolf clan, for the Rime of the Frostmaiden campaign, it is recommended to end the adventure after the first act concludes. See {@creature Thruun|IDRoTF-TTE}'s stat block converted to 5e statistics.

Further exploring the idea behind the god of the hunt, all the folk of Dougan's Hole could belong to a secret cult of Malar. If you choose this route, there is a {@link popular supplement about Malar|https://www.dmsguild.com/product/285018}

A detect magic spell will reveal a faint aura of conjuration magic on the stones and the area in between them. Frost giant Garagai's grandfather was a powerful skald who created this formation to serve as a teleportation circle. To learn the sigil sequence needed to activate the circle, a character must find a way to look at the runes engraved at the bottom of the stones.
{@link Several ideas|https://www.dmsguild.com/product/339075} to create your own encounters with the stones can be found here.

entries.name: Easthaven
entries: Generations ago, Easthaven's boom led to the city becoming wide and spread out. Building within a confining wall was unthinkable. Newcomers prefer making their own houses instead of restoring existing ones, leaving the town with many abandoned buildings throughout. Compared to other towns in the region, Easthaven folk are relatively young, but their dreams of a prosperous future came to an abrupt halt with Auril's winter. Similar to Bryn Shander, the townsfolk are cosmopolitan, with people from many backgrounds found here.
Consult the {@adventure Town Encounter|IDROTF-TTE|-4|town encounters|0} table in appendix B to see what events can occur in this city.

entries.name: Friendliness: 2/3
entries: Easthaven attracts all kinds of people and welcomes them with open arms. The inhabitants range from honest, simple folk to the best of con-artists.

entries.name: Services: 3/3
entries: All sorts of weapons and adventuring gear can be found in the marketplace or select shops. A few temples tend to healing and other needs.

entries.name: Comfort: 3/3
entries: After the Eastway was constructed, taverns and inns became the most lucrative businesses in town. Visitors can always find a comfortable place to stay or dine.

entries.name: Banrock's Mithral Pot
entries: {@i Luxurious tavern}

Banrock's Mithral Pot is extremely popular and even known by those outside of Icewind Dale. The building is expertly crafted from shadow-wood, keeping the rooms warm and cozy. Banrock (lawful good gold dwarf {@creature thug}) is the owner. He is a plump dwarf with black hair and brown skin. He loves to cook and stroll from booth to booth, chatting with visitors. His signature pottage is well known for its rich flavor and nourishing effects. A character who eats Banrock's pottage has advantage on Constitution saving throws against exhaustion for the next 24 hours.

A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals the auras of abjuration magic from the {@spell arcane lock} spells cast on the kitchen's windows, doors and other protective wards on the cookware. Banrock's expensive mithr al cookware is worth enough to allow him to retire. These arcane wards were made by an old wizard friend of Banrock who visits every solstice. Cookware removed from the house will glow brilliantly, bright enough to be seen shining through simple covers like sacks. Similarly, stolen pots will ring every minute they are outside the kitchen, emitting a deep tone sounding as if struck with a hammer, which can be heard from up to 300 feet.

entries.name: The Big Fat Knucklehead
entries: {@i Fishermen's tavern}
