On most afternoons and evenings, this rough and tumble lakeside tavern will be filled with hardened dalefolk, mostly of whom are fishers. There is no shortage of loud laughing and frequent swearing patrons. The walls of the tavern are decorated with countless trophies: stuffed knucklehead trout, scrimshaw, exquisitely crafted fishing tackle, and paintings of brave fishers defying the dangers of Lac Dinneshere.

Flug the Blind (lawful good Illuskan human {@creature commoner}) is an old man with an eye patch who stands behind the counter serving food and drink. He is a small man with short, thin hair. A deep scar runs from under his eye patch through his left eyebrow which is wider than any hook could rip. He tells everybody a wondrous tale of a stormy night when he caught so many small trout that he was continuously unhooking fish until an unlucky wave knocked him off balance, causing him to rip out his eye accidentally. Not wanting to miss out on this magical night of fishing, he continued to fish, using his eye as bait, catching two trout simultaneously. In truth, he lost his eye when his fishing tackle splintered after a long fight against 'Big Knuck' (see {@adventure "Easthaven Town Hall"|IDRotF|-7|easthaven town hall (t1-t10)|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}). Flug regularly tells his fictitious version to entertain guests but mostly to comfort himself because someone else caught Big Knuck, robbing him of his chance for revenge.

entries.name: Cairn's Crossing
entries: {@i Drafty old inn}

Traveling merchants frequently visit the oldest inn in the town sitting near the Eastway. The inn is run by Vie Witters (lawful good Damaran human {@creature commoner}), an old but still lively grey-haired lady. Most assume she is a widow, but she is married to a stubborn local fisher named Bott (lawful good Illuskan human {@creature commoner}). Bott spends all day fishing on the lake and sleeps in the small shed near the inn at night. Vie won't let him sleep inside while he reeks of trout, which is almost always.

The rooms in the main two-story building are drafty but spacious. Guests receive two keys, one for their room and one for the solid wooden chest inside each room. The two-story shed contains a kennel for dogs and axe beaks, space for sleds, and storage upstairs which Bott uses as his bedroom.

Cairn's Crossing and the White Lady Inn have always been rivals. When asked about the town, Vie can describe locations but tries to dissuade guests from visiting the White Lady Inn, referring to Rinaldo's reckless seances, which have brought harm to many participants. She can also recount the tale of the ghost (see "Lac Dinneshere" in {@i Legacy of the Crystal Shard}). Because her husband spends most of the day on the lake, he knows the spot where the White Lady is seen most often, probably hovering where her loved one met his demise.

entries.name: Rumors
entries: A traveling merchant named Ayleth Whitetrail (neutral good Illuskan human commoner) currently resides in the inn. She is a tall, slender woman with black braided hair. She comes from Bryn Shander and can share a few rumors that might interest the characters. Roll two times on the Ten-Towns Rumors table (see {@adventure "Tall Tales"|IDRotF|12|tall tales in ten-towns|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}) to determine what she knows.

entries.name: Grove of the Winter Tree
entries: {@i Temple of Silvanus}

Half a dozen silverbark trees stand entwined on top of a hill overlooking Lac Dinneshere. They form a 20-footdiameter circular grove with a single entrance. Surprisingly, this thin line of trees offers remarkable protection against the harsh winds while still providing good views outside the grove. A wooden bowl filled with silverbark tree seedlings stands on top of a small altar.

At night {@dice 2d6} men and women (chaotic neutral {@creature cultist|MM|cultists}) gather here. They listen to Tohin Gherchoba (chaotic neutral Rashemi human {@creature cult fanatic}) preach of Silvanus, telling the gathering a time will come when they will need to restore the town back to its natural beauty, similar to when the town was small and lived in harmony with nature. Tohin is a short, muscular man with dusky skin and unkempt black hair. If Tohin or his followers come under attack, or if someone tries to destroy the grove, four {@creature twig blight|MM|twig blights} and two {@creature vine blight|MM|vine blights} emerge from the trees to fight.

When a character prays to Silvanus for at least one hour, roll a d100. If the roll is lower than the character's level, one of the silverbark seedlings starts to glow, and that character gains the {@i Charm of Twigs}.

entries.name: Charm of Twigs
entries: This charm allows you to summon {@dice 1d4} twig blights as an action. The twig blights will defend you and fight following your mental direction. The twig blights wither away after 1 hour. Once used, the charm vanishes from you.

entries.name: Hall of Endurance
entries: {@i Temple of Tempus (god of war) and city garrison}
At the center of Easthaven stands the Hall of Endurance. It is a temple dedicated to Tempus and simultaneously a garrison for the city. The temple clergy are mostly reghed barbarian descendants.

entries.name: Courtyard
entries: The complex is surrounded by an 8-foottall stone wall with two entrances into the inner courtyard. Two {@creature guard|MM|guards} stand post at each entrance. The courtyard has a mannequin-filled training ground, an axe and spear throwing range, and access to all temple buildings. During the day, {@dice 1d4} clerics of Tempus (human berserkers ) will be here instructing {@dice 2d8} {@creature guard|MM|guards}.

entries.name: Captain's Residence
entries: The residence of militia captain Imdra Arlaggath (lawful good half-elf veteran) includes her private rooms and a large meeting room with detailed maps of the region pinned to its walls.

entries.name: Barracks
entries: The three-story barracks has a common room and a small kitchen with a pantry on the first floor. The upper floors consist of large bedrooms where each soldier has their own bed, chest, and weapon rack. The building can house up to forty soldiers. There are currently {@dice 4d6} soldiers sleeping and relaxing here.

entries.name: Armory
entries: The two-story armory contains several boxes and racks filled with new weapons, armor, and other equipment.

entries.name: Stables
entries: Inside the stables, there are two sleds and two kennels holding 6 dogs each.

entries.name: Temple
entries: Thick walls, heavy double doors, and narrow windows give the temple a fortress-like appearance. Paintings on the walls of the main hall depict battle scenes of soldiers fighting orcs, adventurers striking down a white dragon, humble dalefolk defending themselves against a yeti, tribal hunters courageously charging at dangerous prey, and many other scenes. The paintings surround a single statue of a knight in full plate armor. The temple also contains modest rooms for the clerics who spent more time training in the courtyard than in the temple itself. There is a 50 percent chance of meeting Cayia Sedrit (neutral Illuskan human {@creature priest}), a cleric of Tempus praying in the main hall. She is a muscular, fair-skinned woman with a light brown braided ponytail and neatly cut sides.

entries.name: Healing
entries: Characters can buy healing services from the clergy here.

entries.name: Harbor Market Square
entries: {@i Market}

Directly between the docks and the town hall lies Easthaven's market, a sight to behold in this cold town. Although its physical size might be smaller than other towns, the number of merchants it contains is only eclipsed by Bryn Shander's market. Characters have ample opportunity to restock their supplies and upgrade their equipment here. Store fronts and smaller stalls are kept close together to fend off the region's cold winds. Merchants loudly advertise their wares, including fish, scrimshaw, everyday necessities, adventuring gear, weapons, and even rare oils and ointments.

What makes this market so different from others in Ten-Towns is the number of false merchants. For every five stalls, one is likely a fraudulent business trying to swindle you. Numerous con-artists are pretending to be honest merchants. Years of experience have made it difficult for even expert traders to separate the false merchants from real ones. Only local residents know who the charlatans are, having memorized their faces. The con-games may range from promising you the stars to offering low-quality replicas. One merchant might offer potent potions to develop a good reputation while also selling worthless mixtures.
This is all completely legal in Easthaven. Locals won't reveal which merchants are trustworthy. And even if they do, how do you know the person identifying the fakes is not the one lying?

entries.name: Bad Weather
entries: The open market offers little protection against the weather. When the weather becomes unbearably cold, merchants close their stalls for the day.

entries.name: Cackling Chasm
entries: When characters walk through the market, they notice Remo and Ahmali Moarskull discussing birthday presents for their son. They are discussing how difficult it will be to brighten his mood since his grandmother Nabira went missing and was presumed dead. They wonder if her magical fishing hook ({@adventure "Cackling Chasm"|IDRotF|12|cackling chasm|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}) would be a perfect gift and serve as a memento for him. If characters engage with the couple, they share what they know of Nabira's disappearance, which is she tried fishing at the Redrun river between the lakes but was attacked by something. They suggest asking the militia captain Imdra for further details.

entries.name: Scams
entries: If characters talk to a merchant, they haven't met before, they have a 20 percent chance of encountering a charlatan. These folks will first determine what the buyers are looking for and then carefully choose their words so they can't be held accountable later. To detect their scam, a character must succeed on an Intelligence (Investigation) check with a DC equal to {@dice 10 + 1d8}. Consult the scams table below to see what they offer.

rows: The potions look and feel like it will  have the desired effect, but they  don't, or the effect lasts shorter than  promised.

The items are poorly forged or made  from cheap material but coated to  appear good. After some use, a  weapon gains a -3 penalty to attack  and damage rolls while armor gains a  -1 or -2 penalty to their AC.

The items don't last as long as promised (torches, oil, candles, and  such burn for only a few minutes) or  have some undesirable side effect  (the ink smells like dung or bandages  from a healer's kit lead to an  infection, poisoning the treated  creature).
The items are made from cheap  material or poorly manufactured.  After some use, they rip or break,  becoming unusable and worthless.

At first glance, everything looks in  order, but after a thorough  inspection, it becomes evident that  components are missing (a card deck  missing a few cards, thieves' tools  without a file or scissors needed to  disarm traps).
Hidden weights in the wares or the  packages betray the actual amount  of trade goods.
Half of the wares are in order, while  the other half is missing or fake.
The wares are offered at an attractive  discount because they were recently  stolen, and the owners are currently  searching for them.
entries.name: Scams
entries.caption: Scams

entries.name: Pomab's Emporium
entries: {@i Trade house}
In contrast to the old buildings surrounding it, this store was recently rebuilt. What stands out most is its brightly colored outer walls and an oversized sign proclaiming 'POMAB'S EMPORIUM.'

Entering this shop might suggest to some there is no need for the Easthaven market itself. Every inch of the store displays some object for sale. It seems as if the owner wanted to sell every kind of product possible. The wares include finely wrought jewelry, precisely carved scrimshaw, smooth marble statues, expensive porcelain tea sets, exquisite Zalantar-wood chairs, strangely realistic paintings, old books and letters, various sized clockwork constructs, and many more. Randomly placed among these items are dozens of polished silver coins.

However, the longer one examines the store's contents, the stronger one feels that everything is incomplete and unfinished. A gem hangs loosely in a ring's clasp. The carving on a wooden fish remains unfinished on half of the trout's head. A marble statue's back is crude and untouched. A tea set is missing cups. A painting is unfinished as if someone lost interest in it halfway. Several books are missing pages. The clockwork constructs ticks, but nothing moves.

Visitors are met by Pomab Ak'azmhir, a calishite man dressed in wide red robes that one might wear in much warmer climates to protect against the sun. Pomab wears numerous layers of this clothing to be comfortable even in this cold region. He welcomes visitors with a friendly smile and overbearing gestures.

The original Pomab is actually long dead. The one standing before the characters is a young dragon named Virainith, who had a dispute with a powerful wizard about eighty years ago. The wizard turned the dragon into this humanoid form. After losing his true form, Virainith wandered Faerûn until he came to Easthaven, where people mistook him for the missing Pomab. He found Pomab's old shop and decided to stay and rebuild it, intending to run the store until he is old enough to hopefully change his form on his own. Helping to make this decision was that he enj oyed Banrock's cooking. Virainith uses the statistics of a {@creature young silver dragon}, except he has a speed of 30 feet and his available actions are those of a typical humanoid.

Pomab trades with everyone for everything. While it might seem, he is the one creating half-finished items, Pomab actually buys them. He feels drawn to them as they remind him of his own situation. Buried under all these halffinished items is Pomab's actual tr ade goods. He can sell all standard gear and equipment. In addition, if asked about a specific potion or scroll (of third level or lower), Pomab has a 50 percent chance he may have the item hidden somewhere. He also owns a few common magic items. Choose or roll for three {@filter common magic items|items|rarity=common|miscellaneous=magic} every tenday, which he has bought from traveling merchants.

entries.name: Invisible Duergar
entries: Pomab warns new customers that he knows the location of everything in his shop. If asked why he explains that he believes someone has been surveying his shop for several days. This is true. Durth Sunblight (see {@adventure "Easthaven Ferry"|IDRotF|12|tall tales in ten-towns|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}) chose his shop as a target to gather more chardalyn but was deterred by the young dragon's extraordinary alertness.

entries.name: White Wyrm
entries: If asked about rumors, Pomab tells customers of the Great White Wyrm often seen hunting in western Icewind Dale (see {@adventure "Wilderness Encounters"|IDRotF|12|wilderness encounters|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}). The dragon has never attacked Ten-Towns directly, and he hopes it stays that way. Someone unfortunate enough to encounter the dragon should hide and pray because no sled can outrun her.

entries.name: Potion of Polymorph
entries: The young dragon Virainith has spent several years trapped in this humanoid form and is becoming restless He plans to brew a polymorphing potion in hopes of breaking the spell still affecting him. If characters enter his shop, he will ask them for a favor. He wants a particular arrow from his friend Trovus, the speaker of Caer-Konig: He wants a used; and now nonmagical, {@item arrow of slaying|DMG|arrow of dragon slaying} which Trovus keeps from his adventuring days. Trovus knows Pomab's true identity and would give the dragon this arrow for free; but if strangers ask for it, Trovus will ask them to solve the recent town thefts first.

Returning the arrow earns the characters the trust of the dragon. Virainith will then ask them to bring him the fang of a winter wolf, the claw of a yeti, and a fin of some aquatic monster. He tells them about the winter wolves in Dougan's Hole and the monster terrorizing Bremen: Virainith has no idea where to find a yeti though. He cautions the characters if he believes they are too weak to directly confront these beasts and rewards them with 50 gp for each of those ingredients.

When the characters deliver all of these items Virainith makes a final request. He wants the characters to go to the tiefling Nowhere; the owner of the Subtle Solution in Bryn Shander to obtain a vial of {@item wyvern poison} by trading a fistsized case. The case he hands them is warded with an {@spell arcane lock} spell and contains one silver dragon scale.

Once Virainith has all ingredients; he throws them into a small cauldron filled with Dragonfire Brandy. He pierces his thumb with the arrow adding a few drops of his own blood, then stirs the concoction while mumbling incantations in draconic. He then impatiently starts to drink from the cauldron; only to abruptly stop and double over in pain: Before someone can react; he {@spell polymorph|PHB|polymorphs} into a tiny lizard. Because of his innate magical abilities; the effect only lasts for 10 minutes, after which he returns to his humanoid form disheartened. If the group doesn't steal from his shop or otherwise abuse his trust while polymorphed; Virainith will reward them the rest of the {@item potion of polymorph|IDRoTF-TTE|potion}, filling exactly one vial.

entries.name: Redrun River
entries: {@i River and fishing spot}

The fishing community of Easthaven suffers from the encroaching ice and not enough fishing territory for everyone. Some desperate fishers now try to catch trout in the Redrun river flowing from Lac Dinneshere into the Redwaters Lake, but twice in the past fortnight, locals have not returned. Captain Imdra Arlaggath offers a bounty of 50 gp for anyone brave enough to deal with the wild beasts she assumes are causing this.

A successful DC 13 Wisdom (Survival) check allows a character to find the remains of fishing equipment covered in blood near the Redrun. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, a character finds hyena footprints in the ice and covered by snow.

If characters spend 1 hour here, they are ambushed by a gnoll raiding party, consisting of 3 {@creature gnoll|MM|gnolls} and 2 {@creature gnoll hunter|mpmm|gnoll hunters}. The gnolls are ravenously hungry, have one level of exhaustion, and advantage against being charmed or frightened. They try to overwhelm the weakest-looking targets first but will flee if there is one of them left. If any gnoll escapes, it runs back to their hideout to inform the rest of their clan ({@adventure "Cackling Chasm"|IDRotF|12|cackling chasm|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}). Bringing proof, they have killed the gnolls is enough for Imdra to pay the characters even if there is evidence that more gnolls may still exist.

items: Very weak: remove 1 {@creature gnoll} and 1 {@creature gnoll hunter|mpmm}
Weak: remove 1 {@creature gnoll hunter|mpmm}
Strong: add 1 {@creature gnoll flesh gnawer|mpmm}
Very Strong: add 1 {@creature gnoll} and 1 {@creature gnoll flesh gnawer|mpmm}

entries.name: Rurden's Armory
entries: {@i Blacksmith}

Rurden's Armory is one of the few outlets selling fine dwarven goods. Rurden (lawful good shield dwarf {@creature veteran}) filled every inch of the store with racks, boxes, and barrels of weapons and armor, enough to outfit the whole town in one go. Thick stone walls, reinforced windows, and a massive, barred steel door give the building the image of a garrison.

Characters will find all types of weapons and armor for sale -even plate armor. None of the weapons or armor are order-made. Customers will find most items are high quality but of heavier dwarven make. All equipment bought weighs 50 percent more than the normal. Rurden is more than happy to show characters how to alter their swings and postures to compensate for the heavier equipment, telling them happily: 'Once you go dwarven, you never go back.'
Characters who enter the shop for the first time in a tenday have a 50 percent chance that Rurden will offer a special discount on one specific weapon because he forged a few too many of them.

entries.name: Impure Chardalyn
entries: Rurden is one of the best smiths in Icewind Dale and can forge anything a person may think of. He has no personal experience working with chardalyn but is willing to give it a try, even offering to buy some if the characters offer to sell him shards. If the characters sell him impure chardalyn, Rurden will gradually turn lawful evil after working with it (see {@creature Chardalyn Berserker|IDRotF} in appendix C Icewind Dale Rime of the Frostmaiden). He will demand more and become more aggressive while doing so. If this happens before the duergar's plot is stopped, the duergar kill Rurden to steal his chardalyn. If this occurs after the duergar are dealt with, the militia will arrest Rurden for murdering a resident, whom he thought had chardalyn.

entries.name: Snowdrift Inn
entries: {@i Shabby inn}

Located near Pomab's Emporium in eastern Easthaven, the exterior is covered in well-weathered wood. The large racks hung with knucklehead trout are braced against the building giving the inn a fishy smell. The common room offers a single large brazier whose smoke leaks through cracks in the roof. Drilmaut Stiz (lawful neutral Illuskan human {@creature commoner}) is a grumpy semibald middle-aged man who offers only cheap ale and no meals to customers. His inn has only three small guest rooms, each furnished with two beds. Drilmaut's main promotion to customers is that his drinks and rooms are half the price of other inns in the town.

entries.name: Stables
entries: {@i Stables}

The town's stables are a complex of a single large building and several smaller structures surrounded by a 10-foot-tall iron fence. Its yard is divided into several dozen fenced-off kennel areas. Olamin Snowburrow (lawful good lightfoot halfling {@creature commoner}) runs the stables along with her four employees.

Olamin buys, sells, and rents sleds, dogs, and axe beaks. At the moment, she has {@dice 4d10} trained dogs, {@dice 2d6} axe beaks, and {@dice 2d4} sleds to offer (see {@adventure "Getting Around Ten-Towns"|IDRotF|1|getting around ten-town|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).

She is welcoming with a great love of animals. She tries to get to know potential buyers before every deal. If Olamin feels the new owners are caring people, she may offer them a 10 percent discount. On the other hand, if she distrusts customers, she will not sell them any animals.

entries.name: Axe Beak Course
entries: Olamin offers to teach characters on how to handle axe beaks. The training takes three hours and costs 10 gp per person. To learn these skills, a character must roll three DC 10 Wisdom (Animal Handling) checks and succeed on at least two of them. A character who completes the training no longer has disadvantage when handling axe beaks (see {@adventure "Getting Around Ten-Towns"|IDRoTF-TTE|1|getting around ten-towns|0} in the introduction) .

entries.name: Run Away Dog
entries: If characters buy from Olamin, she will ask if they are on their way to Caer-Dineval. One of her dogs escaped through the fence and is now missing. She wants the characters to search for it. She suspects the dog has run north along the shore to chase some birds because this would not be the first time it has done so. She checked nearby, but apparently, the dog has wandered farther this time. She will pay them 20 gp if they safely return the dog. The dog can be found playing with a group of children in Caer-Dineval (see {@adventure "Ruined Watchtower"|IDRoTF-TTE|2|ruined watchtower|0} in Caer-Dineval).

entries.name: Town Hall
entries: {@i Town hall (and speaker's residence)}

entries.name: City Speaker's Chambers
entries: Governing the chaotic town of Easthaven can be exceedingly demanding, so at some point, Danneth Waylen took up residence in one of the rooms in the town hall (T15), leaving only three rooms in the building empty. His room is simply furnished with two cabinets for clothes, a bed, and a chest for his personal belongings.

entries.name: Dispute
entries: When characters first enter T2, they find a merchant in a heated argument with the town hall clerk Prudence Tarkwold. The merchant was fined 20 gp for a minor offense. Enraged by this charge, the merchant paid his fine in 2000 cp stored in two small chests that he dropped onto the clerk's desk. They will not yield the position, with Prudence arguing that she can't reasonably accept and count a fine paid this way, while the merchant insisting there is no rule prohibiting it. Characters can help resolve the situation by either offering to help Prudence count the coin, which will take two hours to do, or exchange the coin with their own. Optionally, they can convince one side to give in with a successful DC 15 Charisma (Persuasion) or Charisma (Intimidation) check. If they side against the merchant, he is likely to hold a grudge against them. In the future, the characters might find themselves unable to buy something or denied lodging at a local inn because the merchant has called in a favor to punish the characters.

entries.name: Vellynne
entries: There is a 25 percent chance to encounter Vellynne Harpell investigating the lore of Icewind Dale in the library (T14). Vellynne arbitrarily reads through books and then leaves after a few hours. She learns about Jarlmoot (see {@adventure "Jarlmoot"|IDRoTF|12|jarlmoot|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}) and Angajuk's Bell (see {@adventure "Angajuk's Bell"|IDRoTF|12|angajuk's bell|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}) in some old tomes.

entries.name: The Wet Trout
entries: {@i Popular tavern}

entries.name: Worshipper of the Frostmaiden
entries: Nymetra, the owner of this inn, wears her Auril symbol proudly over her clothes. She will not allow any blasphemy of Auril and won't hesitate to throw people out of her tavern for doing so. On the other hand, when someone displays their own symbol of Auril she will offer them a free drink. Once someone earns Nymetra's trust, she may ask them to secretly destroy the memorial at the southwest gate of Bryn Shander. She believes it is a profane sight that will attract Auril's anger. She is willing to pay 50 gp to anyone who brings proof of its destruction.

entries.name: Clerics of Tempus
entries: A group of four priests (human {creature berserker|MM|berserkers}) from the temple of Tempus use the tavern as their favorite meeting place after a hard day of training. They know Nymetra's faith and prefer not to talk about gods or religion while here. If a violent conflict erupts in the tavern, they will be the first to try to stop it. If someone draws their weapons against them, they will beat them down and throw them out into the cold.

entries.name: Good Mead
entries: As with other towns, humans make up most of the townsfolk, but there is a handful of tabaxi who left their tropical homes to flee to the bitter cold of Icewind Dale. They used their unique expertise to cultivate Good Mead's renowned bees. Tabaxi homes are decorated with simple winter-sturdy plants, colorful tapestries depicting circular mazes, painted urns, and decorations crafted from antlers and forest animal bones rather than fish. Their decorations were not crafted to honor their culture but simply give them a comforting sense of home.

Both floors are similarly equipped. Wooden hexagonal hives are placed between countless nectar-rich potted flowers and plants. Many tiny holes allow the tens of thousands of bees to enter or leave constantly. Hinged sides allow easy access to retrieve the hive's honey. A 10 -foot-diameter hole in the ceiling directly above a pool of water allows the bees to circulate between floors.

entries.name: Friendliness: 2/3
entries: Many of the townsfolk have been influenced by the friendly nature of their former city speaker. After recognizing a newcomer means no harm, residents will be friendly but still display a somewhat distant attitude.

entries.name: Services: 1/3
entries: There are no shops in town. People have little to offer and can share none of it with strangers.

entries.name: Comfort: 2/3
entries: This small town doesn't have a tavern or inn. Newcomers who make friends with the townsfolk may be offered a place to rest in the temple near a brazier and given a few blankets.

entries.name: Mead Hall
entries: {@i Purveyor of Good Mead's honey wine}

This building is the pride of the town and was constructed from the hulls of reused fishing ships. The structure's sol id construction remains in good shape and sealed with resin to protect against the cold. Its thick walls are adorned with images of wyverns dancing in the skies over flowering fields full of swirling bees, and large windows recall a time when the bright sun still illuminated its interior. The wall facing the forest contains several small holes allowing bees to enter. A simple trap door closes over the holes at night or when the weather gets too harsh.

entries.name: Precious Honey
entries: Outsiders are not allowed inside the building. Good Mead is quick to defend their Mead Hall, assembling their full force within 1 minute if alarmed. Every character who enters the building and is not proficient in Animal Handling must make a DC 10 Wisdom (Animal Handling) check every 10 minutes. If a character fails this check three times, a swarm of bees attack, dealing 1 piercing damage at the start of every turn to characters on the same floor not wearing protective clothing. The bees will calm down after 30 minutes if left undisturbed.

entries.name: On the Street
entries: {@i Location}

While traveling the streets of Good Mead, a young girl named Azuil Untapoor (chaotic good Chultan human {@creature commoner}) tries to catch the c haracter's attention. She calls to them from a hiding spot within a group of trees. If the characters engage with her, she asks them to be quiet because her parents told her not to speak with strangers, but she has a very important concern and needs their help. She asked her parents how babies were made, and they told her about the bees and the flowers. But she searched the mead hall, and there were no babies inside!! She offers the characters a tour through the mead hall to convince them of her point of view.

If they agree, she first leads them to the speaker's house, where she slips through a narrow window, returning a few minutes later with a key. A successful DC 10 Charisma (Persuasion) or Charisma (Deception) check convinces her to open the door to the speaker's house for them. Any attempt to intimidate her will frighten her away.

Three massive fireplaces have dozens of clay pipes protruding from them. These pipes move hot smoke from the fires along the ceiling and through the second floor, helping to distribute heat and keep all rooms in the building warm.

She then leads them to the mead hall. A successful DC 10 Dexterity (Stealth) group check allows them to enter unnoticed. The building is currently unoccupied because of a problem with the verbeeg. Azuil brazenly guides the characters for 30 minutes through the building while not wearing any protective gear and will belittle any attempts to wear protection with childish mockery. She is proficient in Wisdom (Animal Handling) checks and therefore isn't required to make checks to avoid agitating the bees (see Mead Hall). During the tour, Azuil tells them of her dream of opening a pastry shop like the one she visited in Easthaven once. She doesn't understand why the adults produce the mead. She tasted it, and it is an awful waste of sweet honey!

When they leave the building, Azuil turns to the characters and demands their explanation of how babies are made. After a short while, they get interrupted by Olivessa Untapoor, who was searching for her granddaughter. She thanks the characters for watching over the child but reminds them the folk of Good Mead don't appreciate unauthorized entry to the building. Before she brings Azuil home, she asks if the characters have a moment because she has a request (see {@adventure "Electing a New Town Speaker"|IDRoTF|8|electing a new town speaker|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).

entries.name: Shrine of the Flaming Sword
entries: {@i Shrine of Tempus (god of war)}
This building consists of a single large prayer room with a spiral stair in its center leading to a small spire reminiscent of an archer's guard tower.

entries.name: A Giant's Blade
entries: The stair encircles an enormous 15foot-long greatsword. Its ancient iron blade is painted with red dye. A character touching the blade must make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the character envisions themselves in a sea of flame which is abruptly extinguished by a biting cold blizzard. Once the snow clears, the character now stands amidst a circle of seven massive thrones seated with shimmering frost giants who look fiercely down at him. The moon hangs high above, while the most imposing giant speaks in a droning voice: 'You are not worthy yet!'. Numbing cold seeps from the ground into the character dealing 14 ({@dice 4d6}) cold damage, after which the vision fades. This effect can only happen once. A character who knows or learns about Jarlmoot (see {@adventure "Jarlmoot"|IDRoTF|12|jarlmoot|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}) can make a DC 10 History check. On a success, the character connects the location to this vision.

entries.name: Speaker's House
entries: {@i Speaker's residence}

The dead city speaker Kendrick was not blessed with a green thumb. Many of the plants that filled this house have withered away in their pots. Kendrick was an optimist who kept watering the dried husks in hopes that someday they might grow. The house's flo ors are covered with colorful woven carpets giving visitors a warm welcome compared with the dull white outside world. The house is filled with Chultan mementos providing a larger and more luxurious space than others in the town.

entries.name: Lonelywood
entries: Folk from Lonelywood are usually quiet and reserved. Homes often contain secret compartments to store weapons, mementos, or other questionable items. Many townsfolk are eccentric, strictly following their own moral code, and would never kill someone on a whim. Despite their Sembian heritage, townsfolk prefer seclusion over the allure of coin and are clever enough to hide what they don't want others to know.

entries.name: Friendliness: 3/3
entries: People came to Lonelywood to escape their past. They are generally friendly or pretend to be so long as you don't ask questions about their past.

entries.name: Services: 2/3
entries: There is one small shop in town offering a selection of goods.

entries.name: Comfort: 2/3
entries: The only inn in town is now used as a warehouse. However, the welcoming city speaker may let travelers stay in her warm and dry attic.

entries.name: The Happy Scrimshander
entries: {@i Shop}

entries.name: Vellynne
entries: There is a 25 percent chance to encounter Vellynne Harpell in a discussion with the owner Iriskree. Vellynne tries to gather information about Revel's End and the Arcane Brotherhood mage Vallish Gant (see {@adventure "Revel's End"|IDRotF|12|revels'end|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}). She also hopes to leverage Iriskree's contacts and knowledge of the shadier aspects of TenTowns. When someone enters the store the two women abruptly halt their conversation.

entries.name: Pavel's Used Goods
entries: {@i General store}

This inconspicuous building stands on the edge of the forest. It has only a 20-foot-square store accessible by a front and back door and no apparent private rooms or storage. Open cabinets displaying wares are rotated away from windows. A secret trapdoor behind the counter leads to a stuffy cellar that owner Pavel (chaotic neutral Turami human {@creature bandit}) uses as his private room.

Pavel is a talkative middle-aged man with dark mahogany skin and curly black hair. He sells his goods at a 25 percent discount and is easily talked into giving larger discounts when people buy several items at once. Pavel doesn 't bother trading for items of little worth. Items he has available for sale include various pieces of light armor, a few weapons, and adventuring gear worth at least 2 gp. He keeps no large stock of any item.

entries.name: 'Used' Wares
entries: When a character openly carries an item bought from Pavel around Ten-Towns, that character has a chance of being accosted by the items' previous owner, who was not compensated for its loss, or attacked by parties who have mistaken the travelers for its last owner.

entries.name: Rumors
entries: Pavel feels threatened by the persistent attacks of the white moose and asks well-armed characters to kill it. He offers no reward but lies, claiming that speaker Nimsy Huddle is offering a 200 gp reward for the beast's head. Pavel also occasionally has contact with Macreadus (see {@adventure "Black Cabin"|IDRotF|12|black cabin|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}), who supplies him with goods. For a 10 gp payment, he gives characters an exaggerated tale about the gnome inventor, his magical gadgets, and the directions to the gnome's cabin.

entries.name: Queen's Garden
entries: {@i Shrine of Mielikki (goddess of the forests)}

In the woods, a short distance from the town, is a small clearing with a garden shrine built by Catti-brie, one of Drizzt Do'Urden's companions. Inside a 15 -foot circle of snow-covered grass stands an ancient hollow tree stump. Engraved on the outside of the stump are peaceful scenes of unicorns striding through forests with smaller animals playing nearby. The hollow interior contains carvings depicting druids calling down lightning and rangers firing arrows at hordes of orcs and goblins. These scenes show the defense of Ten-Towns as well as offensives against orc and goblin settlements.
Characters proficient in druidic can recognize symbols hidden in these scenes and gain the following information:

items: The location of an elven tomb hidden in the forest. The directions require only one successful DC 15 Wisdom (Survival) check to follow landmarks and avoid being veered away by its ancient elven magic (see {@adventure "The White Moose"|IDRotF|9|the white moose|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).

The location of Angajuk's Bell. This is a small anchorage where you can summon Anga's talking whale companion. The whale knows the Sea of Moving Ice and can bring you anywhere within the icy waters for a price (see {@adventure "Angajuk's Bell"|IDRoTF|12|angajuk's bell|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).
A prompt to strike down any orcs of the Many Arrow Tribe who dare set foot into Icewind Dale.
"About ten miles upward the river, you'll find what Ol'Bitey was searching for. Don't take too much!" (see {@adventure "Ol'Bitey's Longing"|IDRoTF-TTE|2|ol'bitey's longing|0} sidebar in Bryn Shander)

entries: A character with the {@adventure "Drizzt Fan"|IDRoTF|20|drizzt fan|0} secret background (see appendix B of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}) knows of this location and has heard of wisdom hidden there.

entries.name: Ramshackle
entries: {@i Closed inn}

This drafty building shows signs of hasty construction. It has gaps showing between misaligned planks sealed roughly with resin. Several parts of its roof were rebuilt, having previously collapsed under heavy snow loads. Its doors scrape the floor on uneven hinges.

Inside the building, a 10-foot-wide corridor opens onto two 30x20 foot rooms on each side of the hall. Doors that once closed off these rooms were removed and now and lean against the nearby wall. The rooms on the left side share a pitiful fireplace on their adjacent wall, but no such heating exists on the right side. The corridor ends in a rickety set of stairs leading to the attic.

The wet and moldy attic has four small rooms that are only 6 feet high. They seem to have been the propr ietor's private rooms. Two rooms contain plain beds removed from the first floor, stacked on top of each other. The third includes a tiny, hardly used hearth and what one could call a kitchen with a lot of imagination. The last room and the only one with a lockable door is filled with a set of broken furniture, including cabinets, a bed, and a moldy empty chest.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The proprietor's bed frame includes a hidden compartment that can be discovered with a successful DC 14 Wisdom (Perception) check. The compartment contains a rusty dagger of venom that will break and lose its magic after one successful hit. There is also a leather pouch holding {@dice 3d10} sp and {@dice 2d10} gp, and 4 tourmalines that initially appear worth 50 gp each. However, these semi-precious gems are fake, which can be discovered with a successful DC 10 Intelligence check using jeweler's tools. The tourmalines are worth only 1 gp each.

entries.name: The White Moose
entries: An awakened {@creature fox|IDRoTF} sleeps in an unused room at night. It was enchanted months ago by Ravisin and employed as a spy in Lonelywood and Termalaine. If caught or persuaded with food, the fox offers basic information about Ravisin and the white moose (see {@adventure "The White Moose"|IDRotF|9|the white moose|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).

entries.name: Speaker's House
entries: {@i Speaker's residence}
This house's appearance is described in the White Moose quest of Lonelywood.

entries.name: Abandoned Sled
entries: If characters tell city speaker Nimsy Huddle about the sled they found outside Termalaine (see {@adventure "Abandoned Sled"|IDRoTF-TTE|2|abandoned sled|0} in Termalaine for more information), she can tell them its owner is Adrof Dag, an old trader who lives in the town. He would travel every two tenday to the eastern Ten-Towns selling his lumber there at higher prices. He would often barter and be willing to wait a few days to get the best price for his wood. He left Lonelywood just two days ago, and astute characters might recognize this is not enough time for him to have returned from his trip. If a character suggests this might be a murder, Nimsy asks them to investigate further. She can only pay 40 gp as a reward but is willing to give them 20 gp upfront to undertake the task. She pays the sum with a large number of silver and copper coins.

entries.name: The Lucky Liar
entries: {@i Tavern}

The tavern's bar is erected in the center of the common room, with stools and tables surrounding it. The counter allows the barkeep Danae to see and hear the customers at every table. The tavern's sturdy wooden beams are engraved with dragons and lions, as is common in Lonelywood. However, Danae commissioned the artist to include bare-chested warriors fighting them, giving the art gladiatorial touch she likes because of her Thayan heritage.

entries.name: Rumors
entries: The ale is half price (1 sp for a gallon, 2 cp for a mug), encouraging customers to drink a lot. Drunken patrons talk loudly, allowing characters to overhear rumors without directly speaking to them. Roll once on the Ten-Towns Rumors table (see {@adventure "Tall Tales"|IDRotF|12|tall tales in ten-towns|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}) to determine the current gossip they can hear.

entries.name: Targos
entries: While the town's wooden wall provides valuable protection against the dangers of the dale, it has considerably hindered the city's growth and affected the townfolks' outlook. Most of the inhabitants are downtrodden and resigned to a difficult life that is unlikely ever to improve. People are stuck in their old ways, adhering to outdated traditions, and opposing the change of any sort. Expanding an ancestral home is frowned upon, forcing residents needing space to look elsewhere, with many seeking opportunities in Bryn Shander or Easthaven. This limited growth transformed into a population drain with the arrival of the everlasting winter. Numerous houses lie empty, and the ring of shacks squeezed against the town's walls are now sanctuaries for criminals and shadier organizations in the town.
Consult the {@adventure Town Encounter|IDROTF-TTE|-4|town encounters|0} table in appendix B to see what events can occur in this city.

entries.name: Friendliness: 2/3
entries: The streets of Targos are more empty than other large towns in Icewind Dale. The townsfolk keep their heads down and get their work done. Characters who go out of their way to be friendly may find some folk receptive and helpful.

entries.name: Services: 3/3
entries: Being the second largest town in the region, characters may find everything they need in Targos in various shops, but shopkeepers may not be as friendly as those in Bryn Shander.

entries.name: Comfort: 2/3
entries: Targos isn't known for catering to travelers. Most inns and taverns are unrefined, rough around the edges, and provide modest services.

entries.name: On Route
entries: {@i Location}

The merchant Gali Rigges (lawful good Tethyrian human {@creature commoner}) stands on the street, halfway between the market and the main town gate, complaining to herself. Beside her is a dog sled she is having trouble with because it is overloaded with trout destined for Bryn Shander.

Gali is a strong-willed, muscular woman with brown eyes and brown shoulder-length hair. She is in her twenties and lives alone with her father. Normally her father would help with this delivery, but he recently hurt his back, and now Gali is stuck trying to move it herself.

The sled is so overloaded with fresh trout that the dogs are not strong enough to pull it to Bryn Shander's market without at least two people pushing. Traveling to Bryn Shander should take 2 hours. Characters willing to help Gali push the sled must make three DC 14 Constitution (Athletics) group checks during the journey.

After the first failed check, Gali starts to sing in a surprisingly beautiful voice, giving everyone advantage on their next check (see {@adventure "Gali's Song"|IDRoTF-TTE|3|gali's song|0} in appendix A). For each failure, the journey takes an additional 30 minutes.

If the group failed at least one Constitution check during the journey, once they arrive in Bryn Shander, they must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or suffer one level of exhaustion. Groups who failed all three Constitution checks make this saving throw at disadvantage.
Gali rewards groups who help her with the biggest knucklehead trout (worth 25 gp).

entries.name: Dwelling
entries: {@i Home of Keegan and Garret Velryn}

The one-story home of Keegan and Garret (see {@adventure "Mountain Climb"|IDRotF|10|mountain climb|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}) stands adjacent to the Luskan Arms. A fenced area creates an open-air kennel adjacent to the house, within which is the only door into the house. The smell of their six dogs is always present in the spacious common room. The wooden floor is messy, showing many paw-shaped water stains. Three scratched leather couches are placed in a semi-circle in front of a fireplace. The dogs sleep on the couches, but Keegan will place clean blankets over the couches for visitors to sit on. A simple kitchen stands to one side. Dozens of storage shelves are mounted high on the wall, out of the reach of the dogs.

A door leads to the couple's bedroom, which the dogs are forbidden to enter. In the far corner of the room stands an ornately engraved workbench covered with a wide variety of saws, files, hammers, chisels, and other tools. Two open boxes hold a collection of unworked fish and animal bones, while two trays display expertly carved scrimshaw trinkets. Keegan's craft is highly respected in town. Few can compare to his skill. Given the right material, he can fulfill any decorative wish.

entries.name: Frostsail Harbor
entries: {@i Harbor}

Running along the east side of Targos sheltered harbor stand seven structures owned by the Dockworker's Guild. It is the only guild in Targos and all of TenTowns. These buildings include shipbuilding workshops, laborer's barracks, and luxurious accommodations for high-ranking guild members. There are also large warehouses full of lumber, lines for sails, rope, and other construction materials.

One of the highest-ranking members of the guild is Giandro Holfast (lawful evil Damaran human {@creature bandit captain}). He is a master shipwright and the official face of the guild. He is a shrewd man in his forties, with tawny skin, black hair, and a strong jaw. Some might consider him handsome if not for his perpetual frown. He is the former city speaker and is native to Targos, and he still has influence in every corner of the town. Giandro lives on the second floor above the biggest workshop and keeps his residence opulently furnished. The apartment contains ornate furniture carved from exotic weirwood, marble sculptures inlaid with gems, and huge paintings illustrating heroic scenes of sailors enduring storms or catching giant fish. Two grimlooking men (lawful evil human thugs) guard the stairs to his apartment day and night.

Giandro has become a member of the Zhentarim in hopes of expanding the guild's grip and force every fisher and shipbuilder in Targos to join. With the help of the current city speaker Naerth he hopes to make the guild mandatory, introduce docking fees, and regulate the lumber price, netting him a substantial personal profit and even more political power. At the moment, the guild controls about 90 percent of the town's fishing business, with only a few hard-headed fishermen still refusing to join.

Guild members must pay a monthly fee of 5 sp. Members enjoy benefits ranging from discounts on ships and equipment, boat rentals, and getting loans with cheap rates. The guild will rent only shabby boats to non-members for 20 gp per day. Further, they offer a protection service that members get for free. This scheme should pressure folk into joining the guild as Zhentarim thugs secretly damage competitor's boats in minor but obvious ways. The marks are used to highlight the poor quality of non-guild workmanship compared to the guild's superior shipbuilding cra ft.
The Zhentarim use the Dockworker's Guild as cover for their smuggling or other nefarious operations. All large ships built by the guild include a secret compartment only known to Zhentarim members.

entries.name: Gallaway Trade Depot
entries: {@i Trade House}

The Gallaway Trade Depot is found in the Ash Quarter, a neighborhood almost destroyed by Akar Kessel l's destructive magic one hundred years ago. The trade depot building consists of two very different halves. One side still shows the centuryold building's blackened wood siding, with the other half is made of newer construction.

The trade depot is now run by Tap Tap (neutral {@creature kenku}), a long-time employee. The previous owner disappeared after refusing to follow town speaker Naerth's demands to report on every new customer, especially adventurers. After Naerth had the owner 'removed,' Tap Tap saw the opportunity to be more than someone's lackey. Although she believes she is technically still Naerth's servant, she now owns the trade depot!

Tap Tap prides herself on keeping the depot running. The kenku ensures the business remains well organized. She keeps new wares in the newer half of the building and cheap or used items stacked in the old half. She enthusiastically welcomes new customers, at least as much as a kenku can. She later uses her mimicry to report all she meets to Naerth.
The trade depot sells adventuring gear, weapons, and cheap armor.

entries.name: Kenku Mimicry
entries: Kenkus lack their own voices and cannot speak normally, but can perfectly mimic sounds they have heard, including other people's speech. They use this ability to communicate with other creatures; creating interesting social encounters. Here are a few example phrases Tap Tap could repeat:

items: In a calm, business-like voice; sounding very much like Targos' speaker Naerth: "It is so good to see you again... How have you been?" good
In a deep booming voice; "Say hello to my little friend.
In an accusatory voice with a heavy elvish accent, "You smell like beef and cheese!"
In a male voice with a self-important tone, "I'm kind of a big deal. People know me"
In a very calm slightly unnerving voice: "...the customer is always right."
A sly; enthusiastic voice asks;, "So you're telling me... there's a chance!"
In a heavily accented voice full of panic, "My hands! The gloves do nothing!"
A disappointed voice respondes, "Yeah, well, you know, that's just like, your opinion man."
A shocked female voice exclaims, "The elves went too far!"
A voice incredulously exclaims, "Inconceivable!"
In a high-pitched woman's voice with an angry, demanding tone: "I want to see your manager!!"
An irritated male voice exclaims; "Laugh it up fuzzball."
A frail old man's voice over-enthusiastically exclaims: "Good news, everyone!", potentially followed by the same voice in a disappointed tone: "Wait, that's not good at all."

entries.name: Graendel's Fine Dwarven Craft
entries: {@i Smithy}

A small one-story building made from withered stone is home to Greandel Granitefist (lawful good gold dwarf {@creature veteran}). His house consists only of one room. It is a well-outfitted smithy where he works, eats, and sleeps. In the center of the room stands a huge forge made from solid granite and engraved with dwarven runes praising the dwarven gods Moradin, Berronar Truesilver, and Clangeddin Silverbeard.

The old dwarf is believed to be Targo's longest living resident. He survived the war against Akar Kessell one hundred years ago. He can recount these tales (see "The Crystal Shard" in the introduction of {@i Legacy of the Crystal Shard}), including how Akar incinerated whole blocks in the Ash Quarter with magical beams of sunlight.

Greandel is known for his high-quality wares, but he doesn't keep any st ock, preferring to forge perfect custom pieces for every client. Greandel can forge any weapon or armor. He charges 50 percent more than the cost shown in the Player's Handbook, but they possess one of the following traits:

entries.name: Order-Made (Weapon)
entries: When you roll a 20 on your attack roll with this weapon, the target takes an additional 2 damage of the weapon's damage type.

entries.name: Order-Made (Armor)
entries: While you wear this armor, when an enemy scores a critical hit against you, the damage is reduced by 2.

entries.name: The Luskan Arms
entries: {@i Inn (and the town speaker's residence)}

Nailed against the walls of the common room are the moth-eaten flags showing the heraldry of the five High Captains, each accompanied by a set of rusty, crossed scimitars beneath. The display is completed with a map of Luskan, city of sails. The brittle parchment map is protected from further decay inside a glass-paneled picture frame. A few dingy tables made from wooden planks are scattered in the dimly lit corners of the common room. A broken mannequin with a dagger stuck in its head stands to one side. The mannequin and the wall behind it show countless marks from thrown daggers.

A trapdoor behind the bar leads down into a mediumsized cellar where rotten planks reinforce the frozen dirt and stone. The feces-laced ground, a pungent smell, and the cacophony of squeaks indicate this spot is the source of the rat infestation. Strong timber crates and barrels attempt to guard the inn's food and ale, but some have succumbed to the rat's constant gnawing. Half a dozen tiny cages are set up to catch the rats, with {@dice 1d4} live rats now trapped within. A successful DC 10 Intelligence (Investigation) check suggests whoever set up the traps severely underestimated the number of rats or didn't intend to exterminate them in the first place.

The upper floor of the inn has a long hallway with doors opening into smaller guest rooms. The hallway eventually leads to speaker Naerth's residence, and characters with passive Perception of 12 or higher notices the absence of rat sounds here. Na erth's chambers are divided into two sections. The front section is designed as a meeting room containing a small table, a few chairs, an iron fireplace, and various cabinets lining the walls. If the characters have failed to stop Zarruk's smuggling (see {@adventure "Tharrom's Warehouse"|IDRoTF-TTE|2|tharrom's warehouse|0} in Bryn Shander), they can find the stolen weapons cache here. Naerth still needs to order someone to remove Bryn Shander's insignias from them.

The backroom contains Naerth's sleeping quarters and his three caged {@creature flying snake|MM|flying snakes}. At nighttime, the snakes are set free to roam his chambers. Naerth drilled small holes in the walls allowing the snakes to hunt rats. The snakes also attack intruders on sight, waking Naerth in the process. Every morning he lures the snakes back into their cages with rats caught from the cellar.

The inn's guest rooms are minimally furnished, containing only beds. The doors don't have locks. Except The rooms are rarely cleaned or maintained, though bed linens are sometimes changed. Each room contains four simple beds. Attached under one of the beds is an ornate copper box. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals a faint aura of evocation on it. Each device records all sounds and voices within 15 feet for 24 hours. The devices will reset every noon to restart recording unless halted with the correct command word. Naerth placed them here to spy on guests and will retrieve them after someone has used a room.

entries.name: Market Square
entries: {@i Market}

The market square matches Targos' atmosphere. This small market is home to local merchants who sit quietly in their stalls waiting for customers to approach, never calling them over. Most of the merchants offer fish, fishing equipment, scrimshaw, other local commodities. Only a few scattered traveling merchants will sell weapons or other adventuring gear.

entries.name: Bad Weather
entries: The open market offers little protection against the weather. When the weather becomes unbearably cold, merchants close their stalls for the day.

entries.name: The Trip and Shuffle
entries: {@i Rough Tavern}

The Trip and Shuffle is a rowdy tavern full of thugs and other scoundrels near Targos' main gate. The establishment is simply furnished, almost resembling barracks. The cleanliness of the tavern stands in stark contrast to its customers.

The proprietor Russel (lawful neutral Chondathan human {@creature knight}) was once a Purple Dragon Knight fled his homeland to escape a death sentence for killing a corrupt lord. He has a bounty of 200 gp on his head in Cormyr.

Once Russel lost his trust in justice, he stopped caring about good or evil. He welcomes all guests to his tavern as long as they don't disturb the peace he has built here. This has made his tavern a favorite location for the local Zhentarim to meet.

Russel keeps a greatsword and loaded heavy crossbow hanging above the bar to remind everyone what happens if they don't behave. His plate armor is safely stored away in his private rooms, but he has maintained a habit of always wearing a chain shirt under his clothes.

entries.name: Wolf's Pelt Inn
entries: {@i Inn}

This simple one-story inn faces Maer Dualdon, providing guests with a fantastic view of the harbor. The old establishment has been family-owned for over a hundred years. The inn lost a bit of its charm after the harbor walls were erected, blocking the view of the rest of the lake, but it is still a popular place for the local fishers to enjoy a good meal before or after their work.

The interior is always filled with a haze of smoke, smelling of delicious fish. The appetizing aromas waft in from the doors to the smokehouse or kitchen. The common room also serves as a sleeping area. It is almost always half-filled, and unoccupied sleeping areas near the central fireplace are rare. Despite the constant buzz of guests, Theobold and Jose Winters (lawful good Illuskan human {@creature commoner}) and their five daughters keep the common room and the inn's three private rooms clean and tidy.

entries.name: Black Swords
entries: One of Theobold's daughters is griefstricken. She doesn't talk as she silently serves guests. When asked about her, Theobold shares a story about Karou Salafan (see {@adventure "Black Swords"|IDRotF|4|black swords|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}). Theobold was hoping Karou would become his son-in-law because of his amazing trout cooking skills. He moved to Caer-Dineval to work for their city speaker, but for many tendays, he has failed to reply to his daughter's letters, which is unusual for him. Theobold is worried his daughter might do something stupid like traveling to Caer-Dineval alone.

entries.name: Winter's Breath
entries: {@i Shrine of Auril (goddess of winter)}

A small shrine stands atop a windy hill some two miles to the west of the town, just a little off the road to Bremen. Five sharp-edged, seven-foot-tall stones in a semicircle surround a small dais. The stones are covered with stains of frozen blood, and several hooks are driven into the stone. On top of the dais sits a white marble bowl roughly three feet in diameter. The bowl contains coins and valuables covered in water and protected by a thin layer of ice. People sacrifice their belongings at this shrine in the hope of appeasing Auril.

Auril doesn't care about the am ount given, only how important the sacrifice is to those who give. Characters who sacrifice a significant sum of coin or an item they don't wish to part with are blessed with half a day of mild weather the next time they travel outside of TenTowns. Sacrifices laid atop the bowl sink down through the ice without damaging it. Any nonmagical object succumbs to extreme cold after 15 days. Magical objects transform into ice and water after 30 days.

In total, the bowl contains 184 cp, 79 sp, 32 gp, a silver hairpin (worth 20 gp), and a golden brooch (worth 50 gp). The ice is easily broken, but anyone touching the water takes 14 ({@dice 4d6}) cold damage. Stealing from the bowl or trying to destroy it triggers Auril's wrath. One mile around the shrine is immediately shrouded in inescapable {@link whiteout|https://docs.google.com/document/d/10qxrPN9NolQvAkg3oQQFgVbVxc30zCAdp0NBjcBKqZk/edit?tab=t.0}, and the temperature plummets to -130°F (-90°C). Regardless how far or in which direction characters walk, they will always end up back at the shrine. After 8 hours the weather clears, and surviving characters can again see Targos in the distance.

entries.name: Wandering Light
entries: When characters visit this location at night, there is a 10 percent chance that characters see a cold blue light slowly walking in the distance. It is a {@creature coldlight walker|IDRoTF} aimlessly wandering 100 feet from the shrine. Characters who ask locals about the shrine are warned about them.

entries.name: Termalaine
entries: Most of Ten-Towns import of exotic wood, high quality silk, fine goat wool, and beautiful marble. These goods typically arrive in Termalaine for further processing. The city houses some of the richest folk in the Frozenfar. While Bryn Shander is Icewind Dale's market hub, Termalaine is the center for art. Jewelers, artisans, and enchanters are highly respected in the city. The town's buildings are built for beauty rather than utility with engraved columns, curved roofs, domes, statues, caryatids, opulent decorations, spacious design, and treed alleys. Without the snow and if the town's buildings were made of sandstone rather than wood, the settlement might resemble portions of the great desert city of Calimshan. The town is home to many low-level spellcasters focused on creating beautifying enchantments. Inhabitants are used to seeing magic in everyday life.
Consult the {@adventure Town Encounter|IDROTF-TTE|-4|town encounters|0} table in appendix B to see what events can occur in this city.

entries.name: Friendliness: 3/3
entries: Probably the friendliest folk in Ten-Towns. They pride themselves on living in the most beautiful town and want to ensure travelers appreciate this too.

entries.name: Services: 2/3
entries: The town specializes in artistic goods and services. Finding a traveling merchant selling adventuring gear or weapons can sometimes be challenging.

entries.name: Comfort: 3/3
entries: Taverns and inns in the town are popular for two reasons, their comfort, and their friendly staff. Travelers will always be welcomed and find a warm place to stay. Termalaine is also the only town in Icewind Dale with a working theatre.

entries.name: Abandoned Sled
entries: {@i Location}

Three miles away from Termalaine, on the way to Targos lies the overturned sled of Adrof Dag. Zhentarim from Targos killed him and stole the lumber he was going to sell in Easthaven. The Zhentarim staged the scene to look like a bear attack after killing him. They stole the dogs and turned the sled to make it appear it was heading to Termalaine. They then covered their tracks and threw Adrof's body into Maer Dualdon. They transported the lumber using a separate sled before loading it onto a small ship. A Zhentarim messenger stationed in Termalaine notified the nearby ship with a flying snake allowing it to intercept the merchants.

When the characters arrive on the scene, no one is in sight, there are no sled dogs attached, and the sled is empty of goods. An inspection reveals fresh animal footprints nearby. A ripped dog harness suggests the dogs may have fled. Traces of blood indicate the owner of the sled likely didn't survive. The sled is decorated with carvings of lions chasing goats. One of the runners is heavily bent, making it impossible to use it until repaired by a smithy. A craftsman would demand 5 gp to fix the runner.

A successful DC 13 Wisdom (Survival) check identifies the animal tracks as being made by a bear. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the character will also notice the deliberately obscured tracks of several booted feet around the sled. If they follow the footprints, they will find traces of another sled leading to the ice of Maer Dualdon, which vanish close to the water.

A successful DC 12 Intelligence (Investigation) check determines it is highly unlikely that the dog sled's runner could not have been damaged in the crash and may have been intentionally bent using tools or a weapon.
Characters scouting the area have a 25 percent chance of encountering a {@creature snowy owlbear|IDRoTF} for each hour they search.

entries.name: The Eastside
entries: {@i Inn}

Innkeeper Marta often sings the following song to herself: "Ahead of winter's wind she came. The lovely woman with no name. Draped in a fur-lined cloak of red. To the icy lake she fled. The wind pursued her all the same. As sure as night she's dead." The following section expands on the explanation given in the campaign book (see {@adventure "The Eastside"|IDRotF|11|the eastside|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).

A young apprentice of a red wizard of Thay fled from the Arcane Brotherhood in Luskan seeking a new life in Lonelywood. She stole some magical items from her former mentor, hoping to sell a few to support her new life. But she underestimated her mentor's tenacity. Once reaching Termalaine, she realized she had no way of escaping the {@creature invisible stalker} her mentor had sent after her. The invisible stalker resented its task to kill the apprentice and retrieve what she carried. So, the elemental gleefully watched how furious its summoner became when it didn't retrieve the ring the apprentice had left with the Peskryk family.

The apprentice didn't go far. A character standing on the docks of Termalaine who casts a {@spell locate object} spell for her red fur coat will sense it. Her remains lie about 700 feet off shore, 100 feet deep on the lake's bottom. Even if Marta never met the woman, she is grateful that the characters made an effort. Marta gifts them her ring of warmth and will bury her to give her a proper rest.

entries.name: The Fluffy Flumph
entries: {@i Upper-class tailor}

The Fluffy Flumph consists of a narrow building squeezed between two large houses. It has a whitewashed facade with a large window displaying two mannequins wearing different styles of winter clothing. The shop is run by Corlin 'Trim' Idwalin Kals hi Halfshoe (chaotic good rock gnome {@creature commoner}). She is a 4-foot-tall gnome with smooth brown skin, intricately braided auburn hair with unsecured strands standing in all directions. Trim has a happy-go-lucky attitude and forgets everything around her when asked about clothing and design. Trim has no clue what a flumph is. She just picked the name because it had a nice ring to it.

Her shop is barely big enough to hold the several large rolls of silk, fine goat wool, and other exotic fabrics, half-a-dozen mannequins, and her human-sized counter. A fine fabric curtain covers the entrance to the back room. It is a small room containing a large fabric working surface along with a tiny bed.

Trim sells high-quality textiles and Icewind Dale styled winter clothing. She dresses in the latest Waterdeep fashions and is in tune with the latest styles thanks to regular correspondence with her brother, who lives in the city. She can tailor clothing for everyone's needs and sells both ordinary and magical dyes. She owns magical dye in dark blue, light violet, red, orange, sunny yellow, grass green, grey, snow-white, and night black. These magical dyes instantly change the color of any object rubbed on and cost 50 gp per application.

entries.name: Luminescent Dye
entries: Trim asks characters carrying weapons if they are interested in escorting her to Dougan's Hole. She found a book in a strange language depicting clothes in bright lights and colors. After some research, she learned of a luminescent flower from which she could make a new dye. She offers a 25 percent discount on all future purchases as a reward if the characters help her find this flower and bring her back safely.

Additionally, she will dye one item with the new dye for free. Dyeing an object with the new flower dye creates a permanent enchantment that sheds dim light in a 5foot-radius. The book she discovered is written in netherese language Loross (see {@adventure "Loross: The Netherese Tongue"|IDRotF|16|loross:a the netherese tongue|0} sidebar in chapter 6 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}), and named 'Power in Fashion, Part VI.' It contains detailed instructions for creating a {@item cape of the mountebank}, a {@item cloak of the bat}, a {@item cloak of protection}, and {@item glamoured studded leather}. A {@spell comprehend languages} spell or the artifact Professor Skant can help with the translation.

entries.name: Market Square
entries: {@i Market}

The market of Termalaine is a sight to behold as every stall is adorned with carvings. The merchants try to impress buyers with their intricately crafted stalls, with the carvings indicating what wares are offered. Carvings of fish and waves suggest a food merchant, musical notes imply a crafter of instruments or decorative wares, and stalls with carvings of animals, wizards, or homunculi may offer more exotic goods.

The market is renowned in Icewind Dale. It is one of the most picturesque locations in the town, with wind chimes filling the air with a mysterious ambiance. Dozens of expertly crafted shrines and sculptures praise either Sune, the goddess of Beauty, or Milil, goddess of Poetry and Song. The merchants are friendly and willing to barter and may even provide guidance to another more suitable stall.

Most of the traders offer gems, aesthetic goods, artistic services, baked sweets, or daily commodities. Only a scattered few traveling merchants will sell other gear. No one in the market sells weapons of any sort.

entries.name: Bad Weather
entries: The open market offers little protection against the weather. When the weather becomes unbearably cold, merchants close their stalls for the day.

entries.name: Mistruvvin
entries: {@i The only theatre in Icewind Dale}

Malo Loudbellow (chaotic good halfling {@creature commoner}) is the theatrical director and co-owner of the Mistruvvin Theatre. He has a burning passion for acting but has stagefright and is a notorious worrywart. Malo's impassioned arguments convinced Mistruvvin (chaotic good {@creature faerie dragon (blue)}) of the magnificence of theater that the faerie dragon offered her small hoard to purchase a building and open the theatre. Mistruvvin is highly motivated to make the theatre a success despite being ignorant of what's involved in running a theatre or putting on a show.

The theatre consists of a large hall filled with dozens of chairs in front of a simple wooden stage. Multiple mechanisms allow a small crew to make numerous impressive set changes and change the stage's appearance. This stage includes a thick curtain, background images that slide on rails, continual flame enchanted light sources, catwalks with ropes and rigging, and so on. Hidden behind the stage is a small control board to manipul ate the stage's mechanism. A stair ascends from this room to the attic, where the props and costumes are stored.

entries.name: A Premiere to Fail
entries: Malo was planning to premier his first production on the day the characters arrive. Guests have come from all over Ten-Towns. He sits depressed by the backstage entrance as a number of his crew abandoned him only a few hours ago, bribed by an unknown person. In truth, Malo is horrified by the thought that people may ridicule his efforts. He is trying to sabotage the play to have an excuse for its failure. He would prefer to see his theatre idea fail glamorously to convince himself that his dreams aren't worth pursuing so he can go back to his ordinary life as cleric of Gond in the Tower of Ingenuity.
Malo's three-act play is about the legacy of the crystal shard. It depicts Akar Kessell's war against Ten-Towns and presents the glorious victory of the drow hero Drizzt and his friends.

If the characters decide to assist Malo, he asks them to do whatever is needed to keep the show going, including acting as background extras or help disguise mishaps that may occur during the show. A handful of mishaps secretly instigated by Malo himself will happen, forcing the characters to improvise or intervene quickly. Different skill checks such as Acrobatics, Performance, Sleight of Hands, etc., may determine how effective the characters' actions are.
The premiere of the first play at Termalaine's Mistruvvin theatre is facing several challenges. Here are a few plot hooks to get the characters involved:

items: City speaker Oarus Masthew has heard rumors of problems at the theatre. A successful theatre would help lift the spirits of the town's desperate folk. He asks the character to help out ensuring the premier succeeds.
Gladells Irlin Glasshopper from the Tower of Ingenuity helped construct the theatre's numerous stage mechanisms and wants to see them in action.

An acquaintance of the group bet Malo his production would be a resounding success. Should the play succeed, the acquaintance will win the bet receiving something of value from Malo. The acquaintance asks the group to do what they can to ensure the play is a success.

entries: If you want to have characters play a more active role in the play check out this {@link encounter idea|https://www.reddit.com/r/DnDBehindTheScreen/comments/6ktcx4/encounter{@i putting}on{@i a}play/}.

rows: The correct costume or prop is missing.
A kenku actor or orator hasn'tshown up and needs replacement.
The mechanism that moves the curtain is stuck.
Numerous dogs enter through a backstage door and chase after meat hidden in the drow hero Drizzts pockets.
entries.name: Mishaps Between the Acts
entries.caption: Mishaps Between the Acts

entries.name: Act 1 - Introduction
entries: The show starts with the drow ranger Drizzt with his magical panther, the dwarf Bruenor, the human Catti-brie, and the halfling Regis working together to thwart a barbarian attack. They meet the young barbarian Wulfgar and together help bring a time of peace. Years pass before a mage named Akar Kessell finds the crystal artifact Crenshinibon, which helps him enslave orcs, goblins, trolls, and the reghed barbarian king Heafstaag.

rows: A hearing-impaired stagehand atop the catwalk misses hearing "cloudy;' their cue to change the scenery.
A stage light comes loose; threatening to swing and hit the actor playing Wulfgar, the barbarian.
An actor walks on stage, having forgotten one of their props like a sword or an axe.
One of the actors forgets their lines and begins to improvise poorly; sending the narrative in the wrong direction.
entries.name: Mishaps in Act 1
entries.caption: Mishaps in Act 1

entries.name: Act 2 - The Villain's Attack
entries: Akar leads his army against Ten-Towns. He scorches the towns using the artifact's intense radiant beams. Wulfgar leaves to challenge Heafstaag to a duel. Drizzt sneaks into Akar's crystal tower but is caught and imprisoned by the mage.

rows: The recorded scorching noises of Crenshinibon's sunbeam are replaced by a long fart from a comical play.
The wooden planks beneath the villain Akar Kessell break, and he falls, vanishing beneath the stage.

A halfling took over the role of a missing actor playing who was to play dwarf Bruenor. The actor will be lifted into the air by the ropes to simulate a mighty jump; but the counterweights are still set for the weight of the original dwarf actor.
The apparatus that creates mist randomly activates and begins to fill the stage with fog.
entries.name: Mishaps in Act 2
entries.caption: Mishaps in Act 2

entries.name: Act 3 - The Hero Triumphs
entries: Wulfgar is victorious and claims leadership over the barbarians. He defeats the goblins and orcs with the help of the barbarian tribes. Reghis rescues Drizzt and manages to destroy the wizard's tower. Drizzt follows Akar through a magical portal. Atop the Spine of the World, the two engage in a climactic battle until Drizzt forces Akar to unleash the crystal's power recklessly. This causes an avalanche killing Akar and sweeping Drizzt away. Drizzt manages to survive, and the play finishes with a typical happy ending.
In the middle of the final fight scene, a group of hired thugs break into the theatre and storm the stage to attack the actors.

entries.name: Tower of Ingenuity
entries: {@i Temple of Gond}

The Tower of Ingenuity is found in the southern end of Termalaine. The ground around the structure is littered with broken bricks and blackened planks up to one hundred feet away. The wide ground floor is constructed of thick stone blocks. Two smaller stories are built atop this, both made of wood. The wood walls appear new. Numerous gaping holes encircled with burn marks are covered in canvas.
