A reinforced bronze door automatically opens when touched, revealing a cramped foyer littered with material, including boxes and barrels filled with wood rods, copper gears, iron chains, sheets of canvas, and other tinker's supplies. A hole in the ceiling allows for goods to be lifted to higher floors. The floor is covered in soot. Countless footprints carve a network of tracks leading to a damaged spiral staircase and many doors that lead to small adjoining workrooms. At the far end of the foyer stands a 6-foot-tall steel construct supporting a 2-foot-diameter gearwheel which serves as an altar to Gond, the god of craft. Eight Gond Bells (worth 10 gp each) are attached to the massive gear, one from every gear tooth.

Knocks and shouted greetings go unheard, drowned out by the buzzing rattle of mechanical contraptions and tinkering work that can be heard coming from behind the many closed doors. After a few minutes, Craftsister Gladells Irlin Glasshopper (chaotic good rock gnome {@creature priest}) enters the foyer and is surprised by any visitor before greeting them. Her light grey skin is covered in dirt. She is only 3-foot tall, which is small, even small among gnomes. She compensates for her height by talking incessantly on a seemingly never-ending stream of topics... and a ladder. She has a brilliant mind and is open to new ideas, but her clumsiness often results in her many inventions having rather abrupt and explosive ends.

entries.name: Source of Smoke Powder
entries: The crafters in this tower occasionally work with {@item smokepowder|wdh} to the dismay of Termalaine's other residents. Gladells has a contact in Lantan who can provide her with more of the dangerous material.

entries.name: A Severed Bond
entries: Before visitors leave, Gladells asks them for a favor. After a harsh disagreement, two of her friends left the temple. She hasn't heard from them in a while and would be grateful to see them return and mend their friendship. She tells them of either the rock gnome Copper Knobberknocker who lives in the attic of the House of the Morninglord in Bryn Shander or his best friend Macreadus in the Black Cabin north of Lonelywood (see {@adventure "Black Cabin"|IDRotF|12|black cabin|0}). As a reward for helping to reunite with her friends, she offers the characters any tinkering help they may need to repair or improve items at a discounted price.

entries.name: Town Hall
entries: {@i Town hall (and the town speaker's residence)}

The town hall is the artistic centerpiece of Termalaine. Covered passageways extend meticulously designed curved roofs, giving the appearance of a domed structure. The roof is well constructed and can withstand heavy snow loads. The front waiting room includes a magnificent 30-foot-high ceiling containing two desks between a collection of caryatids depicting various gods. A highly decorated spiral staircase ascends to a secondfloor gallery that overlooks the entrance chamber providing access to the city speaker's private offices. The entrance chamber includes an ornate door opening into a large hall where town meetings are held. The walls of this meeting hall are illustrated with several large murals depicting all forms of artistic craft.

entries.name: Abandoned Sled
entries: If characters tell the city speaker Oarus Masthew about the sled they found outside Termalaine, he is likely to conclude the incident was an attack by a ferocious animal. He suggests such attacks are common now that the winter has become harsher. With his many political enemies, he can't risk accusing people from Targos without solid evidence. He is willing to pay 75 gp if the characters bring him the carcass of a freshly slain craig cat, yeti, or snowy owlbear as proof that the immediate danger has been dealt with. The decoration on the sled tells Oarus that the sled was owned by a trader from Lonelywood, likely heading back after selling lumber.

entries.name: Sacrifices To Auril
entries: Roll on this table to determine the person who will be sacrificed on a new moon.

rows: If the characters have a residence in town, one of them is randomly chosen. Otherwise, reroll.
A person the characters know in town is chosen.
A person the characters don't know in town is chosen. Roll on the table below.

entries: Roll to determine the person unknown to the characters.

rows: A gold dwarf named Oghar Strongstrike. He worked in construction and is known for his solid work. He grew angry when he learned heâ€™d been selected. He violently lashed out and almost causing the new structure he was working on to collapse before being escorted out.
A young human named Mari Silvery. She worked as a  waitress in a local tavern. Her husband is heartbroken  and devastated.
A wood elf named Aphir Elemvas. He worked as a  tailor. He strangely didn't say a single word and  accepted the result without showing any emotion.
A forest gnome named Vyrili 'Juggli' Wrolla. She  worked in the town hall and spent her days in the local  orphanage entertaining the children with stories.
An old human named Karrak Brook. He trades  knucklehead trout. He has no family and accepts the  result with composure and without resistance.

A middle-aged human named Rolv de Marbnoy. He was  a traveling merchant selling goods around Ten-Towns.  Before being taken away, he sold all his equipment and  bid farewell to his wife and two daughters.
A young half-elf named Ivy Goldhair. She was the wife  of a rich old merchant in town. He didn't look sad at all.  She furiously shouted profanities at him as she was  taken away.
A middle-aged human named Brom Trivke. He looked  shocked and immediately began to protest. He had to  be forcefully tied to a post.
An old human named Jade Wolffang. She was a retired  mercenary who lived off her earnings procured during  her adventuring days.
A shield dwarf named Kilmol Firebraids. She worked in  a smithy that crafted simple trinkets. Her twin sister  followed her into her icy death.
A white dragonborn named Lakhrarkil. Knowing that  the cold wouldn't kill him, the city tied him to a  post  against his wishes to go of his own free will.
A human boy named Francis. He had just left the  orphanage a month ago when he grew old enough to  live on his own. Apparently, luck was never on his side.
One {@creature winter wolf} leading a pack of {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature wolf|MM|wolves} demanding food; otherwise, they attack.

One  {@creature thug} who hired six {@creature icewind kobold|IDRoTF|icewind kobolds} to help waylay travelers. 3 kobolds sit on the shoulders of each other, posing as two Medium sized humans in thick winter clothing. They emerge from this disguise when they come into melee range.
A signpost or tree covered in icicles. When characters  approach, {@dice 1d4} {@creature ice mephit|MM|ice mephits} attack once using their frost breath and then flee amused by their attack.

The carcass of a large animal with {@dice 1d4} {@creature vulture|MM|vultures} pecking it. The vultures initially launch into the air and fly in circles. After one minute, another {@dice 2d4} {@creature vulture|MM|vultures} join them and attack anyone near the carcass.

{@dice 1d6 + 2} {@creature gnoll|MM|gnolls} trying to ambush travelers from well-concealed positions. 50 percent of the gnolls are sick  with cackle fever. They come from their hideout in the  Spine of the World (see  {@adventure "Cackling Chasm"|IDRotF|12|cackling chasm|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).
{@dice 2d4 + 3} {@creature orc|MM|orcs} robbing one {@creature commoner} and the {@dice 1d4} {@creature goat|MM|goats} on their way to one of the bigger towns.
One {@creature snowy owlbear|IDRoTF}  searching for prey.
A {@creature druid} tending to a wounded cub of one {@creature saber-toothed tiger} which attacks when someone other than the druid approaches its cub.
The corpse of a merchant and one {@creature crag cat|SKT} that is hiding, waiting to ambush any newly arrived prey. The merchant has {@dice 1d10} gp and {@dice 4d10} sp in their pockets.

The group travels near a thicket of shrubs from which they hear cheerful chatter. The voices stop as they approach. The thicket is actually six  {@creature awakened shrub|MM|awakened shrubs}, enchanted by a frost druid to protect animals.  Although they are awakened, they are not very smart. If characters come close, the shrubs 'whisper' to each other oblivious that the characters can already hear them. They ask each other if the two-legged thingies may have heard them. When they can no longer hide, they engage in a naively philosophical debate with  haracters about the meaning of their task. They ask  the characters if they believe that they are supposed to
{@dice 1d4} fisher ({@creature commoner|MM|commoners}) trying in vain to push a broken sled full of trout to the nearest town.

One {@item icewind dale trinket|IDRoTF|trinket} (see appendix A of Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden) with a quirk or minor property ({@book "Special features"|DMG,7,special features,0} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}) or one part of a pair of sending stones.

The invisible {@creature faerie dragon (blue)} Mistruvvin (see {@adventure "Mistruvvin"|IDRoTF-TTE|2|mistruvvin|0} in  Termalaine) who plays tricks on travelers with her illusion magic and euphoria breath.

One wounded {@creature giant elk} that has lost 10 hit points and has a crossbow bolt in its rear leg, reducing its speed  by 10 feet. It is scared and has 50 percent a chance of attacking, otherwise, it tries to flee.

One depressed hermit ({@creature acolyte}) with drug induced  hallucinations. The hermit is frostbitten but too crazed at the moment to accept help. They will reward rescuers with a potion of healing the next day if they recover.
{@dice 2d4} {@creature swarm of ravens|MM|swarms of ravens} enchanted by an evil druid to attack any humanoid on sight.
{@dice 1d4} {@creature shadow|MM|shadows} that deal cold damage instead of necrotic damage.

1 {@creature cult fanatic} and {@dice 1d6} {@creature cultist|MM|cultists} of Auril trying to ritually murder Mishann, a {@creature priest} from the House of the Morninglord in Bryn Shander, or another  priest.
Two enormous round eyes with piercing blue irises form in the clouds and scanning the lands for {@dice 1d6} minutes.

A scavenged and half-buried sled extruding a nauseating perfume smell. {@dice 2d4 - 1} sleeping {@creature jackal|MM|jackals} lie around an ochre-colored pool which is the source of the smell. The pool is an {@creature ochre jelly} and will attack anyone who comes near. A creature who breathes the air within 10 feet of the jelly must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or fall unconscious for 1 hour, or until cured with a {@spell protection from poison} spell.

entries.name: Thruun
entries: Thruun is described in "{@link King of the Wolves|https://www.drivethrurpg.com/en/product/168693/dungeon-220-4e}" of the Dungeon #220 (page 32 - 55). It is the origin behind the Stones of Thruun (see "{@adventure Twenty Stones of Thruun|IDRoTF-TTE|2|twenty stones of thruun|0}" in Dougan's Hole).

In the adventure Isarr Kronenstrom summons it. Thruun is described as a shaggy beast the size of a horse, with apelike arms ending in clawed hands. Its wolfish face has no eyes, just a long row flaring nostrils. Twenty severed hands dangle from a cord around its neck.

intro: Roll a {@dice d100} and consult the matching column for the relevant town.

entries.name: Town Encounters
entries.caption: Town Encounters

entries.name: Adventurers
entries: A {@creature veteran} and a {@creature priest} sit in a tavern or on the side of the road drinking, lamenting, and praising their fallen comrades. They are half of an adventuring party that survived the unforgiving conditions of the frozen tundra. They tell a short tale about the landscape, weather, and some monsters they encountered if spoken to.

entries.name: Apprentice
entries: An apprentice ({@creature commoner}) is trying to pull an overloaded sled full of materials. The apprentice is tasked to bring it from the market to the master's shop. A character willing to help must succeed on a DC 10 Strength (Athletics) check to pull the sled. As thanks, the apprentice offers his friendship and may help the characters later. The master could be a merchant or the city speaker of the town.

entries.name: Assassination Attempt
entries: Characters see a well-dressed half-orc walking along the street in front of them. If they have met him already, they recognize him as city speaker Oarus Masthew (lawful good half-orc {@creature scout}). A leather pouch lies on the ground near Oarus. There is a 50 percent chance that Oarus doesn't s ee or ignores the pouch. Anyone opening the pouch is attacked by a black {@creature flying snake} that emerges from inside. The snake attacks with advantage against a surprised creature and then tries to escape back to its Zhentarim owners in Targos. The snake's fangs are tipped with a tiny hook. If the snake hits a creature with its bite, it loses its fangs and cannot use the bite attack again, but the target takes {@dice 1d4} poison damage at the start of each of its turns until the fangs are removed. A creature can use an action to make a DC 15 Wisdom (Medicine) check to safely remove the fangs. On a failure, the wounded creature takes {@dice 2d4} piercing damage, and the fangs are removed. If the check fails by 5 or more, the wounded creature takes {@dice 1d4} piercing damage, and the fangs are not removed.

entries.name: Beggar
entries: A beggar ({@creature commoner}) in rugged clothes grasps a character, desperately begging for money. The beggar lost their livelihood since the arrival of the endless winter and has survived by eating rats. Any character that comes into prolonged physical contact with the beggar must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or contract the sewer plague disease.

entries.name: Blind Seer
entries: A young woman with bandages covering her eyes with a weasel sitting on her shoulder approaches the group. She calls herself a seer and offers a divination for 5 gp. If the characters agree, she tells them a cryptic warning about a foe they'll face in their next battle. The characters gain advantage on their initiative checks for that battle. The seer is Nass Lantomir (see appendix C of Icewind Dale Rime of the Frostmaiden), one of the wizards from the Arcane Brotherhood. She is trying to earn some quick coin before her journey to the Isle of Solstice. She pretends to be blind but uses the eyes of her familiar to make her seem more fantastical.

entries.name: Bump
entries: While passing the characters, two men ({@creature spy|MM|spies}) aggressively demand an apology for a bump they felt when the group passed them. One of the men was jostled by an invisible {@creature duergar} who squeezed between them. A DC 15 Charisma (Intimidation) or Charisma (Persuasion) check will persuade the men to ignore the bump; otherwise, they attack. There is a 50 percent chance that the men belong to the Zhentarim. The footprints of the invisible duergar are lost amongst the countless other tracks on the road.

entries.name: Burglars
entries: Thieves broke through the window of a warehouse, stealing food supplies and loading it onto their sleds. The group consists of one {@creature spy} and {@dice 1d4} {@creature thug|MM|thugs}. If the thieves see that they don't stand a chance against the characters, they try to flee with their half-filled sled to another town where they hope to sell the stolen food.

entries.name: Corpse in a Barrel
entries: A pungent smell assaults the characters. The smell emanates from a damaged barrel dumped in a back alley, surrounded by a {@creature swarm of rats}. The rats attack anyone who approaches. The barrel contains a corpse.

entries.name: Cultists of Auril
entries: {@dice 2d4 + 2} {@creature cultist|MM|cultists} wrapped in white coats damage the windows and walls of a building to let the cold air inside. They resist any attempts to stop them with non-lethal force, believing it is their holy duty to inflict Auril's cold on everyone.

entries.name: Cultists of Silvanus
entries: Tohin (chaotic neutral Rashemi human {@creature cult fanatic}) and {@dice 1d4} {@creature cultist|MM|cultists} from the Grove of the Winter Tree try to sabotage a new unoccupied building under construction. They cut ropes, pierce tarpaulin, and destabilize wooden beams with saws. If someone tries to stop them, Tohin summons {@dice 2d4} twig blights to harass the interloper while they escape into the city

entries.name: Demonic Revenge
entries: An unscrupulous merchant scammed a young man ({@creature commoner}). Unable to compensate for the loss, the young man kidnapped the merchant's wife ({@creature commoner}) and is trying to sacrifice her as part of a demon summoning ritual. The wife is seriously wounded with her blood filling demonic runes. Two {@creature quasit|MM|quasits} are summoned from the runes at the end of every round, up to a maximum of six. The woman will die at the end of the third round if she is not treated with a successful DC 10 Wisdom (Medicine) check. If not stopped, the young man sends all the quasits to destroy the merchant's business. Otherwise, he tries to flee the scene, leaving the quasits to fend for themselves.

entries.name: Drug Addict
entries: A dirty, unshaven man sits on the ground, apparently unperturbed by the cold. A sweet smell originates from his smoking pipe. He doesn't respond when talked to, only uttering teary-eyed mumblings of incoherent things from his past.

entries.name: Drugged Drinks
entries: One of the patrons ({@creature bandit captain}) in a shady tavern posing as a traveling merchant asks the group where they intend to go. The patron offers all of them a drink plus 10 gp if they escort him to one of the smaller towns nearby. The ale is poisoned. Characters who drink the ale must succeed on DC 15 Constitution saving throw or be affected by {@item torpor poison}. The patron hopes to steal the characters' gold and valuables.

entries.name: Drunken Troublemakers
entries: {@dice 2d4} drunk {@creature commoner|MM|commoners} pester characters, insulting them as weaklings and a waste of coin. They argue that if the characters aren't weak, then why haven't they done something about the never-ending winter?

entries.name: Feeding the Hungry
entries: Mishann from the House of the Morninglord, or a different {@creature priest}, distributes small portions of food to a long line of haggard-looking townsfolk. If the characters donate at least 10 rations, Mishann offers to heal them for free the next time they are injured.

entries.name: Followers
entries: Six armed people start to follow the characters. There is a 50 percent chance they are {@creature thug|MM|thugs} looking for a good opportunity to mug the group. Otherwise, they are militia {@creature guard|MM|guards} sent to check if the group are troublemakers.

entries.name: Frenzy
entries: A gnome ({@creature commoner}) stabs a man between the ribs using a black glass shard, killing him instantly. The murderer keeps manically stabbing the dead body. After a few minutes, a militia patrol arrives because of the commotion and tries to arrest the gnome. The shard is a piece of impure chardalyn and has driven the gnome insane. There is a 25 percent chance that an invisible duergar arrives before the patrol and tries to wrestle the shard from the gnome.

entries.name: Funeral
entries: A small procession of {@dice 2d6} {@creature commoner|MM|commoners} in black clothing carry a simple coffin out of the city. They are going to bury their dead friend in a nearby lake.

entries.name: Guard Patrol
entries: A group of four {@creature guard|MM|guards} patrolling the town ask anyone they haven't seen before, their names, what they are doing here, and where they reside. If encountered in Targos, a character who is part of the Zhentarim can dissuade them by saying, "I am just here to earn coin and make a name for myself."

entries.name: Guide
entries: A guide ({@creature scout}) offers safe journeys to other towns for 2 gp per mile. If the guide accompanies the characters, they don't need to roll for any wilderness encounters. There is a 50 percent chance that the guide leaves them at night, in a blizzard or fog-like weather, because the characters have been led into an ambush of {@dice 2d6} {@creature bandit|MM|bandits}.

entries.name: High Stakes Gamble
entries: A {@creature veteran} and two {@creature bandit captain|MM|bandit captains} are playing a dangerous dice game. If a character wishes to join the game, the gamblers offer them a chair but warn their stakes are high. The character must contribute 50 gp or something of similar value to the pot. Whoever scores lowest in each game must chop off one of their fingers, while the highest-scoring player gets to keep the pot. If a character joins the game but later refuses the punishment, the three gamblers angrily decide to enforce the punishment and take an additional finger.

entries.name: Hungry Dog
entries: A dog ({@creature mastiff}) tries to rip off a character's backpack in search of food. The character must succeed on a Strength contest against the dog, or it runs off with the bag. If the dog fails, it tries to attack the backpack in hopes of ripping it open.

entries.name: Little Thieves
entries: Two young kids suddenly come running from a side alley. One jumps the other, throwing them both to the ground. The fight becomes rough, and blood is spilled. Characters distracted by this fight are targeted by children approaching from behind attempting to steal a purse or a small item. The group of children is well coordinated. They lift items simultaneously and flee in every direction, including the two actors. Distracted characters with a passive Perception of 12 or lower are surprised when the children run. Run a chase (see {@book "Chases"|dmg|8|chases} in chapter 8 of the Dungeon Master's Guide) if the characters decide to run after one or more children.

entries.name: Loose Runner
entries: An axe beak sled is stuck on the muddy road because one of its runners has come loose. Characters willing to help must first free the sled, requiring a DC 13 Strength group check using at least three people. Every additional person reduces the DC by 1. Once free, a successful DC 13 Wisdom (Land Vehicle) check enables a character to reattach the runner. As a reward, the merchant offers the characters 10 gp worth of their wares (see A Merchant's Escort table in the introduction).

entries.name: Illusionist
entries: An {@creature illusionist wizard|mpmm} currently using a disguise self spell, tries to lure the group into an alleyway hoping to cast sleep on them using a 4th level spell slot. If all characters fall asleep, the wizard takes the purses of the closest two characters before hastily leaving. If the plan fails, the illusionist casts an invisibility spell on themself and flees.

entries.name: Quarrel In The Streets
entries: A {@creature uthgardt barbarian leader|SKT|barbarian} {@homebrew |A statblock is not provided in the original} from the reghed tribes and a {@creature swashbuckler|mpmm} are in a heated quarrel. Their dispute quickly escalates into a fight with drawn weapons.

entries.name: Rancid Smell
entries: Two neighbors argue vehemently about a rancid smell filling their houses, accusing the other of causing the smell. A successful DC 11 Wisdom (Perception) check identifies a patch of unfrozen ground in the backyard of the two houses as being the source of the smell. Characters can unearth a {@creature zombie} buried underground, holding an orb made of chardalyn. A {@spell detect evil and good} spell reveals the area is desecrated, but nothing else can be divined. During each long rest, characters having the orb in their possession have a 20 percent chance of being plagued by nightmares, being unable to wake up, and remaining unconscious for an additional {@dice 1d6} hours even if someone tries to awaken them.

entries.name: Researcher
entries: Characters see a half-elf looking around town apparently searching for something. She is taking samples of snow and ice while searching. If the characters engage the half-elf, she introduces herself as Dannika Graysteel and tells them she is researching for ways to end the winter. She might ask for assistance to either find some chwingas (see {@adventure "Starting Quest: Nature Spirits"|IDRotF|1|starting quest%3a nature spirits|0} in chapter 1 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}) or to bring her white dragon bones (see {@adventure "Wyrmdoom Crag"|IDRotF|12|wyrmdoom crag|0} in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}).

entries.name: Rich Retailer
entries: A rich merchant with two axe-beak-drawn sleds is on the way to the marketplace. The sleds are loaded with highly valued wares from the south. Two {@creature veteran|MM|veterans} accompany each sled.

entries.name: Scam
entries: A merchant selling potions, ointments, and other consumables promotes his newest creation, a small pouch that creates {@item bead of nourishment|XGE|beads of nourishment} once per day. The salesman offers to sell the pouch for 400 gp but can be bargained down to 150 gp. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals the bag, and its contents, are indeed magical. The merchant has filled the bag with beads of nourishment and is willing to give a serious customer a taste to confirm. However, although the bag is magical, it only creates normal beans which look identical to beads of nourishment.

entries.name: Scavenger
entries: The group sees a mother holding an infant. She is taking the belongings off the frozen body of an old man who didn't survive the night. When the mother notices the characters, she looks to the ground, ashamed but quickly resumes her scavenging. She wraps her child in the dead man's oversized clothes, pushing a single copper piece into her pocket.

entries.name: Stark Cold
entries: A wave of extreme cold washes over the characters. Each character must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or take {@dice 2d6} cold damage. If a character drops to 0 hit points because of this damage, the character gains one level of exhaustion.

entries.name: Starving Urchin
entries: An urchin in ragged clothes walks by the group, only to collapse nearby. The kid is badly malnourished. When asked, the urchin tells them they have struggled since their parents died. Their parents didn't wake up one morning after they couldn't afford to heat their home any longer.

entries.name: Street Food Vendor
entries: An old woman pulls a cart from which she sells grilled fish for 2 cp each. She travels around town and has a lot of customers each day. She has heard most of the rumors in town. Roll on the Ten-Town Rumors table (see "{@adventure Tall Tales|IDRotF|12|tall tales in ten-towns|0}" in chapter 2 of {@i Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden}) to determine her current gossip.

entries.name: Traveling Merchant
entries: A traveling merchant is looking for an escort back to their hometown (see A Merchant' s Escort in the introduction).

entries.name: Threaten The Folk
entries: A group of four {@creature bandit|MM|bandits} corner an old fisherman ({@creature commoner}), aggressively threatening him. They want him to be "less stubborn" and accept the many advantages of joining the dockworker's guild.

entries.name: White Lady
entries: While walking through the streets, the group hears someone calling. The voice is faint and distant. They cannot make out the spoken words, but they hear sorrow in the woman's voice. If they search for the source, the voice vanishes.

disease.name: Malar's Fury
entries: The sight of blood brings on maddening visions of the hunt.

When a creature is bitten by a creature infected with this disease, or when it comes into contact with blood or saliva contaminated by the disease, the creature must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become infected.
It takes {@dice 1d4} hours for Malar's Fury's symptoms to manifest in an infected creature. Symptoms include being agitated and aggressive.

When the infected creature sees a wounded enemy, it must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or fall into a frenzy. While frenzied, it can only perceive wounded hostile creatures, feel compelled to kill them, and has disadvantage on attacks against creatures that are not wounded.

At the end of each long rest, an infected creature can make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a successful save, the DC for saves to avoid falling into a frenzy decreases by {@dice 1d4}. On a failure, the DC increases by {@dice 1d4}.
When the saving throw DC drops to 0, the creature recovers from the disease.

reaction.name: Spell Reflection

The spell targets the chosen creature instead of the original target. The attack roll is rerolled against the chosen creature.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: Thruun has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: Thruun regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn. If Thruun takes radiant damage or damage from a silvered weapon, this trait doesn't function at the start of Thruun's next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Thruun makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claws.

entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. Further, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or contract the disease {@disease Malar's Fury|IDRoTF-TTE}.

entries: Thruun moves up to his speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

Thruun is described in "{@link King of the Wolves|https://www.drivethrurpg.com/en/product/168693/dungeon-220-4e}" of the Dungeon #220 (page 32 - 55). It is the origin behind the Stones of Thruun (see "{@adventure Twenty Stones of Thruun|IDRoTF-TTE|2|twenty stones of thruun|0}" in Dougan's Hole).

In the adventure Isarr Kronenstrom summons it. Thruun is described as a shaggy beast the size of a horse, with apelike arms ending in clawed hands. Its wolfish face has no eyes, just a long row flaring nostrils. Twenty severed hands dangle from a cord around its neck.

reward.name: Charm of Twigs
entries: This charm allows you to summon 1d4 twig blights as an action. The twig blights will defend you and fight following your mental direction. The twig blights wither away after 1 hour. Once used, the charm vanishes from you.

variantrule.name: Herbs of the Frozen North
entries: Despite the chill weather, there is a wealth of unique herbs in the frozen north. Characters who are proficient with an herbalism kit can find and harvest these valuable plants, potentially using them for a number of medicinal uses. Herblore is a valuable skill for those adventuring parties with little or no access to magical healing.

entries.name: Finding Herbs
entries: The DM always has final option to say yes or no on whether an herb can be found, but if you wish leave the presence of a helpful plant to chance, consider the terrain and time of the year.

If a plant is determined to be present, a successful DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check is required to locate it. This check takes one hour and characters who are proficient with an herbalism kit gain advantage on this check. A character who succeeds on a DC 20 Intelligence (Nature) check correctly identifies the herb. Those that fail the check by 5 or more incorrectly identifies the herb as a different herb.

entries.name: Terrain
entries: The terrain of Icewind Dale is varied, but includes:
{@b Fresh Water Adjacent:} Includes the lakes Maer Dualdon, Lac Dinneshere, and Redwaters, or the Redrun stream and the Shaengarne River.
{@b Forest:} The Lonelywood and other small wooded areas such as the small woods south of the Eastway.
{@b Ice:} The Reghed Glacier or the icebergs in the Sea of Moving Ice.
{@b Mountains and Hills:} Includes both Kelvin's Cairn and the Spine of the World.
{@b Valleys:} Areas like Bremen's Run, the Fields of Slaughter, or Icewind Pass.

entries.name: Harvesting and Preparing Herbs
entries: Some herbs can be eaten raw, but others require preparation before they are made useful. Harvesting and preparation requires a successful Wisdom check with proficiency in an Herbalism kit. Herbs spoil a week after harvesting and must be consumed within an hour of their preparation.
{@b Eaten Raw (DC 5)}. The herb need only be properly harvested.
{@b Brewed into a Tea (DC 10)}. The herb is mixed water and steeped at a specific temperature.
{@b Eaten Cooked (DC 10)}. The herb is cooked following a specific recipe.
{@b Poultice (DC 15)}. The herb is mixed with water and mashed to form a paste that is spread over the affected area.

entries.name: Herbs in Icewind Dale
entries: Medically relevant herbs in Icewind Dale are most commonly mosses, lichens, low-growing shrubs, and grasses with flowers or berries found very rarely during the very short summer growing season.

item.name: Potion of Polymorph
entries: When you drink this silvery pulsating liquid, all your senses become overwhelmed: the stinging taste of liquor on your tongue; the numbing cold crawling over your skin, the burning of poison in your veins; as vision and hearing adjust to your new form.

After drinking the potion; you must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw; taking 14 (4d6) poison damage on a failed save; or half as much damage on a successful one. If this damage doesn't reduce you to 0 hit points; you gain the effect of a {@spell polymorph} spell into the form of the beast you are thinking of having a CR of 3 or lower.

item.name: Arctillia
entries: When this rare moss is mixed with water and coal ash in a poultice and spread over the eyes of a blinded creature, it gives it advantage on saving throws to recover from that condition for 24 hours. In order to be effective, the poultice must be left on the creature's eyes for the duration.
{@b Preparation:} {@i Poultice (DC 15)}. The herb is mixed with water and mashed to form a paste that is spread over the affected area.
Also see: {@variantrule Herbs of the Frozen North|KaOSCaTGtID}

item.name: Beorunna's Cure-All
entries: The pale stems of this plant must be boiled into a biter tea that reinforces the patient's constitution when consumed. The character rendering aid gains advantage on Medicine checks made to treat diseases.
{@b Preparation:} {@i Eaten Cooked (DC 10)}. The herb is cooked following a specific recipe.
Also see: {@variantrule Herbs of the Frozen North|KaOSCaTGtID}

item.name: Feverbalm
entries: The small petals of this dark purple flower are steeped in lukewarm water creating a tonic for those suffering from madness. {@dice 1d10} hours after the tonic is consumed, a creature removes one level of Madness.
{@b Preparation:} {@i Eaten Raw (DC 5)}. The herb need only be properly harvested.
Also see: {@variantrule Herbs of the Frozen North|KaOSCaTGtID}

item.name: Ilmater's Breath
entries: Stalks of this grass are chewed raw prior to a long rest and at the conclusion of the rest the creature gains {@dice 1d6} temporary hit points.
{@b Preparation:} {@i Brewed into a Tea (DC 10)}. The herb is mixed water and steeped at a specific temperature.
Also see: {@variantrule Herbs of the Frozen North|KaOSCaTGtID}

item.name: Kaant
entries: When this lichen is rapidly dried over a low flame; it forms fibrous strips called Kaant that accelerate a creature's metabolism. For 8 hours after a creature chews it, the character gains advantage on saving throws to prevent exhaustion due to cold temperatures. However, Kaant rapidly depletes the body's energy; and its users require twice the normal amount of food and water on days they use the herb.
{@b Preparation:} {@i Poultice (DC 15)}. The herb is mixed with water and mashed to form a paste that is spread over the affected area.
Also see: {@variantrule Herbs of the Frozen North|KaOSCaTGtID}

item.name: Mother's Leaf
entries: The leaves of this low, woody bush must be boiled into a tea to be effective. A creature that drinks the tea gains advantage on saving throws against disease for 1 hour.
{@b Preparation:} {@i Brewed into a Tea (DC 10)}. The herb is mixed water and steeped at a specific temperature.
Also see: {@variantrule Herbs of the Frozen North|KaOSCaTGtID}

item.name: Shagron Sweetbark
entries: Stripping the bark from this shrub and brewing it into a tea can help stave off sleep. A creature that drinks the tea gains advantage on saving throws to avoid falling asleep for 8 hours.
{@b Preparation:} {@i Brewed into a Tea (DC 10)}. The herb is mixed water and steeped at a specific temperature.
Also see: {@variantrule Herbs of the Frozen North|KaOSCaTGtID}

item.name: Sourberries
entries: A handful of these pale blue berries eaten raw give a creature advantage on saving throws to resist paralysis for 1 hour.
{@b Preparation:} {@i Eaten Raw (DC 5)}. The herb need only be properly harvested.
Also see: {@variantrule Herbs of the Frozen North|KaOSCaTGtID}

item.name: Trueroot
entries: The red roots of this spindly tuber have the same effect as an {@item antitoxin} when eaten cooked.
{@b Preparation:} {@i Eaten Cooked (DC 10)}. The herb is cooked following a specific recipe.
Also see: {@variantrule Herbs of the Frozen North|KaOSCaTGtID}

item.name: Woundwort
entries: When this small plant is mashed into a poultice and spread over a wound, a creature regains an additional {@dice 1d4} hit points when completing a short rest.
{@b Preparation:} {@i Poultice (DC 15)}. The herb is mixed with water and mashed to form a paste that is spread over the affected area.
Also see: {@variantrule Herbs of the Frozen North|KaOSCaTGtID}
